title: baby boy just three months
story: NewsBaby boy has just three months to live unless NHS funds miracle drug to save himHaris Khans mum Renata and dad Shakeel have called on drug Spinraza, a treatment for Spinal Muscular Atrophy , to be approved before it is too lateShare, to be approved before it is too late" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _JS.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|", to be approved before it is too late" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _JS.jpg" data-tracking"messenger|share|", to be approved before it is too late" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _JS.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|", to be approved before it is too late" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _JS.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|", to be approved before it is too late" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _JS.jpg" data-tracking"linkedin|share|", to be approved before it is too late" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _JS.jpg" data-tracking"flipboard|share|", to be approved before it is too late" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _JS.jpg" data-tracking"email|share|"CommentsBySteve Robson:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsHaris Khan has type  Spinal Muscular Atrophyand doctors say he has just months to live "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe anxious parents of a seriously ill baby boy have voiced their horror that a miracle drug which could save his le has been denied. Haris Khans mum Renata and dad Shakeel learned earlier this month that their son has type  Spinal Muscular Atrophy . The devastating genetic condition affects the nerve cells needed to control the muscles we use for moving, swallowing and breathing. Until November, the NHS funded a treatment named Spinraza, which has been hailed for the impact it has on patients. But it is no longer given to patients after the National Institute for Health and Care Excellencesaid it was too costly to recommend. Shakeel, , told the Manchester Evening News: This is England, its not a third world country.   My family are from Pakistan. Im born here, my dad had cancer removed the day Haris was rushed to hospital but we cant help a little kid whos six months old with a genetic illness  Only a hundred babies a year maximum need that treatment... we, as a country, are losing a hundred babies because we dont think its justied to save them. One in  people are a carrier of the faulty gene and in the most severe cases, such as Haris, children rarely live beyond two years, making SMA the leading cause of death in babies and toddlers in the country. Earlier this month, the parents of seven-year-old Kennedy Mercer described how the drug had changed her le. Her dad Paul said her twin brother Karter would still be aliveSpinraza was prescribed from birth. And Shakil Malji, whose baby daughter Maryam has been diagnosed with the same condition, told : Its terrible that theyve got something available that can treat a sick child and theyre not using it because of money.   The first British girl to receive it, Annabelle Rose Thomas came off breathing support, can swallow food and has even ridden a horse. It remains available in Scotland. Biogen, the company which makes the drug, charges almost pound, for it in the US market. It is offering Spinraza at a lower price of pound, for the first year in the UK, and offered an undisclosed discount to the NHS, but it was still not enough. That it is a heartbreaking decision to accept for Shakeel, Renata, , and Haris nine-year-old step-brother Marijus, who live in Wythenshawe.  On March , the Khan family and friends will be staging a peaceful demonstration outside the headquarters of NICE in Manchester ahead of a crucial meeting. It is expected NICE will announce a decision on whether to once again fund Spinraza on the NHS in England. Babies like Haris are being used as a bartering tool, he said. March  in Manchester is going to be such a big day for SMA-suffering families, becausethis drug is not approved, God only knows what were going to do for Haris. Its such tough times. Were not working now, Im self-employed, my we has had two jobs. But my phone is off - who needs money without a family  Any money in the world is nothingyou dont have a family to enjoy. The best I can do is to save my son, or keep us with us for as long as possible.  SMA has changed a lot in the last  years. Im speaking to people whove been treating their children for the last three or four years and got them to five-years-old with love and dedication. These people give me strength and inspiration that my Haris can do that as well. The world miracle is in our vocabulary for a reason - yes its very rarely used, but it does exist. This is what were clinging on to. From what I can see from Haris, he is fighting. He is fighting hard. When I see him eating, and hugging and smiling. I think I cant give up on you, otherwise Im not a responsible parent. It all seems a nightmarish turn of events from when Haris arrived in the world last August.  He was described as a happy, smiley, friendly baby by staff at Wythenshawe Hospital. But when a health visitor came for an eight-week check-up last Ocotber, she noticed Haris head movement was not normal. Shakeel says this is one of the key symptoms of SMA to look out for. He had no head control at all, its known as floppy baby syndrome, said Shakeel. Everything was floppy, arms, hands and legs. The health visitor asked for an urgent appointment, but Haris was not seen until December .  There he was diagnosed with hypotonia and recommended for physiotherapy once a week. The family believed he was progressing. But at the end of January, Haris became suddenly very ill with a cough and a cold. After several visits to their GP, Shakeel and Renata eventually became so concerned they rang an ambulance. Haris was rushed to Wythenshawe Hospital where his condition rapidly deteriorated and doctors said his respiratory system had collapsed. He was intubated and the family were then rushed back and forth between Alder Hey in Liverpool and back to Manchester due to a lack of available beds. After a week at Royal Manchester Childrens Hospital, the family believed Haris was improving.  In fact, he had been due to have his intubation tubes removed. But following further tests, the Khan family were given the devastating news. They said we need to get you to a meeting, said Shakeel. I walk into the room and something tells me somethings not right. Theres a family liaison, three neurologists, two consultants, a bed nurse and wing nurse. The week before the result, Id been talking to the nurses saying I can accept any result, because I already thought Id lost Haris. They start saying your son has spinal muscular atrophy. I thought spine, muscles, that makes sense because he cant hold up his head. Then they said Im sorry, theres absolutely no treatment and your son has three months to live.  I struggled to comprehend it. Am I actually hearing, what theyre telling me  Then they make it worse saying there was a treatment, its available in Scotland but not in England because the NHS stopped it. Shakeel says his family are doing their best to accept the verdict they have been given. At one stage, they were willing to move to Scotlandthat would give them any more chance of getting Haris the treatment. We would relocate in a heartbeatit meant we could save Haris, said Shakeel. We said to Marijus, we might move and he said he would go anywhere in the worldhe can save his one little, baby brother. Unfortunately, its not that simple. The family have been Scotland would not accept patients who have simply relocated and the treatment is only available for genuine residents. Shakeel says the specialist neurologist who diagnosed Haris is adamant he wont make it to his first birthday. Hes so negative. He never told me there is a baby with SMA type , the same as Haris, who is now two-years-old, said Shakeel. That wouldve been the little bit of hope I needed. My son is going to be dead in three months, Im just beginning my journey in parenthood, Im not going to get to take him to school. There is a one in four chance my next child will have this - we cant have any more children. I cant put an innocent child or my family through that. So for me, my son deserves the best possible care and attention. My family need all the love and support we can get. Fortunately, the Wythenshawe community had already stepped up and shown tremendous support for the Khan family. Every neighbour on their street has a poster in the window about SMA. St Peters primary school have supported Haris brother Marijus and the Rainbow Trust Childrens Charity are helping the family any way they can. Whatever the outcome for Haris and the decision on March , Shakeel and Renata dont want other families to go through the same ordeal. We might only have my Haris for a few months, so Ive got to create a legacy for him, said Shakeel. The NHS dont screen for SMA at birth. Had they screened him in August when he was born, the treatment was available until November on the Early Access Programme. Eighty infants are on that - Haris would have been . Thats one thing were calling for. The other campaign is for treatment for all types of SMA to be available in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.  Haris is the youngest child with SMA to feature on a leaflet being handed out to all MPs this week by the charity Muscular Dystrophy UK. Shakeel wants as many people as possible to be aware of the fight and support the cause. Every SMA parent is waking up thinking is this our sons last day  he said. My sons got the most severe type, thats why we were told he wont make it, they said they havent seen this type in a long time. Until a few weeks ago I thought SMA was a type of baby milk - now I understand what it is. Haris hasnt got a voice, thats why we have to speak up for him. The community is helping us, dont get me wrong - but the people that we need the help from is the NHS. A spokesperson for NHS England said: We understand how dficult and frustrating it is for families waiting for decisions to be taken on the funding of new treatments, which is why the company must price this drug responsibly and at a level which is both cost effective and affordable to the NHS. It is disappointing that Biogen chose to close the Early Access Programme for new patients with Spinal Muscular Atrophy Type  before the NICE assessment process had been completed.A JustGiving page has been set up to raise money to support the Khan familys campaign to improve awareness of SMA. It is also where Shakeel is posting updates on Haris and his battle. You can visit and donate here

story: NewsBurger-loving businessman who couldnt put own socks on loses st in six monthsBenjamin Jay Smith, of Wrexham, north Wales, tipped the scales at st and confessed he "felt like a pudding"ShareCommentsByMark SmithBradley Jolly:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBenjamin Jay Smith, , has transformed his body in six months "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA businessman became so obsessed with burgers and pizzas that he was unable to put on his own socks has lost  stone in six months. Benjamin Jay Smith, , regularly scoffed greasy takeaways, including two double cheeseburgers or  chicken nuggets, for dinner. He ballooned to a whopping  stone and was unable to walk upstairs or even put on his own socks six months ago.But since then, the entrepreneur has fought the flab and lost the astounding  stone. He has also invested poundmillion of his own cash into creating an app to help others lose weight, Wales Online says.Benjamin, from Wrexham, north Wales, said: I was so fat that I couldn’t put my socks on or go upstairs. It was embarrassing. I felt like a pudding. Slimming World turns : Inspiring weight loss stories from last five decades I’ve always been an emotional binge eater. I was addicted to food – high-calorie pizzas were my downfall – and was regularly eating triple the recommended daily allowance. I hated looking at myself in a mirror, was embarrassed about my size, and felt depressed. Benjamin finally decided to shed the pounds when his now we Cara was ill with lipoedema and needed an urgent operation. The long-term condition leads to painful swelling in the legs, thighs, and buttocks. I had to be strong for her. So I changed my focus to only eating food when my body needed it and I cut right back on my high-calorie diet, he said.  I started to exercise and taught myself about nutrition. The super slimmer decided to create the Fine Diet Plan, a fat-busting plan which counts weekly calories. This information allows the team to calculate the user’s basal metabolic rate and, when combined with their occupation and activity levels, works out their optimum calorie intake for weight loss. story: NewsDad relives horric Samurai sword attack that left him blind in one eyeWARNING GRAPHIC IMAGES Jon Barnesm had to have  staples after he was hit in the head during shocking incident in Eastleigh, Hants, just before ChristmasShareBySam Rkaina:,  FEB NewsJon Barnes was struck in the head and suffered a brutal injury "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father has relived a horrying samurai sword attack which resulted in a bloodbath at a friends house. Jon Barnes, , was viciously struck in the head with the sword which left him in a coma for  days. The sword left a wound across the left side of his head which needed more than  staples to seal. Mr Barnes spent more than a month in hospital and says he is lucky to be alive. Doctors told him he was a medical miracle but had to break the devastating news that he had been left blind in one eye as a result of the attack.  The labourer, from Winchester, Hants, was visiting a friend when he was attacked after an argument with one of the other people in the house. Mr Barnes was walking down the stairs of the property in Eastleigh, Hants, when he says he was struck from behind after seeing his assailant grab a sword from under a bed. Neighbours called police after hearing screams and officers dashed to the end of terrace property to be confronted with a bloodbath.  The hallway, which featured Christmas decorations, was covered in blood with a trail out onto the driveway. A neighbour, who did not want to be named, said: We heard people screaming and two ambulances arrived within minutes. When we looked outside there was blood everywhere. Mr Barnes was taken to Southampton General Hospital, where his condition was described as le-threatening. Police launched an attempted murder inquiry and made a series of arrests but no-one has yet been charged in connection with the near-fatal assault, which took place four days before Christmas.  Mr Barnes said: The thing I remember most is the blood, which went everywhere. I was dying on the floor. A neighbour came round with a towel and wrapped it around my head. If they hadnt done that I would have died. Describing the moment he woke up from a  day coma in hospital, Mr Barnes discovered he was blind in his left eye. He added: I put my hand over my other eye and couldnt see a thing. Ive been left with a huge scar on the side of my head and often feel very tired and depressed. He had no reason to do it. Mr Barnes and his partner,  year old Abi Howcroft, finally have something to celebrate - the arrival of their baby daughter Elsie-Rose on February .

story: NewsMum claims p Aldi bath wash left baby boy with singed scalpThe infants horried mum said she had to take the one-month-old to hospital after he went floppyShareByJoanne Welford:,  FEB NewsThe babys mum has shared pictures of the reaction her son had "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA worried mum has shared pictures of a severe reaction her baby son suffered after she used a p bath-time product. She says she couldnt wake him and rang  before he was rushed to North Tees Hospital in Stockton.   Thankfully the tot recovered from his ordeal. title: mum refused hip surgery because
story: NewsMum is refused hip surgery because she smokes two cigarettes a dayLaura Naylor, , was shocked to arrive at hospital to be told she couldnt have the op and needed to attend a six-month non-smoking clinic - despite her stating she smoked on her application formShareCommentsByMichael MutchAmber Hicks:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLaura was shocked by the decision as she had already stated in her application form that she smoked "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has slammed the barbaric decision to refuse her hip surgery because she smokes two cigarettes a day. Laura Naylor, , has suffered from hip dysplasia for the last ten years and thought she was finally going to have the surgery that would change her le. The condition has forced the stay-at-home mum to stop working and she is left in agonyshe walks too far. But she believed the pain was about to come to an end when her application for NHS funding was accepted, reports Hull Live. On the form the mum-of-two clearly stated she smoked one cigarette in the morning and one in the evening. So after forking out pound on Thursday to get to a pre-assesement at Spire Hull and East Riding Hospital, she was stunned to be told by a nurse she couldnt have the operation - and needed to go through a non-smoking clinic for six months. “I was in shock,” said Laura, from Hornsea, East Yorkshire. “I didn’t say much at first and then tried to question why and what was going on.  “They knew I smoked, it was on the forms.   “I never once got told I had to stop smoking, I just got told I needed to cut back.” Spire Healthcare has said Laura’s eligibility for the procedure should have been identied by her GP. A spokesman said: “In this case the patient was transferred to us from Castle Hill and at pre-assessment it became clear that she could not be eligible for this operation due to the current rules set out by East Riding of Yorkshire CCG. “This should have been identied and highlighted by her GP and we have informed her of the steps that need to be taken before an operation can take place.”  With time spent at a clinic and the waiting process to be accepted for funding, Laura could potentially be facing a further two years to have the surgery. She said: “It’s the kids that suffer in the long run because I can’t go far and I can’t do much with them. I do as much as I can. I can have a good couple of days but then I need a day to recover. “I used to go running all the time and the kids would go on pushbikes and come with me, but I can’t do that anymore.” Laura used to work in a cafeacute but had to give up the job because the pain was too much to bear. Now, she is a stay-at-home mum and relies mostly on her parents and taxis to get her around. She said: “I used to work in a cafeacute but it just got to a point where it was too painful. Now, I just stay at home with the kids. All I want to do is go back to work. “I can’t go too far. If I go to get shopping I have to get a taxi back every single day. Everything I do revolves around taxis or asking my parentsthey can help.   “They took me to most of my appointments, but they work so I can’t rely on them all the time.” To rub salt in the wound, Laura found out thatshe had been living in Hull instead of East Riding her status as a smoker would not apply, as the Hull Clinical Commission Groupdoes not have restrictions to smoking. Laura said the dferent rules for separate catchment areas was barbaric. “It should all be the same for everybody,” Laura added. “If that person needs that operation they should have that operation. “It is ridiculous that because I live out of the catchment area and in East Riding that I can’t have that operation because I smoke two cigarettes a day. “Why doesn’t Hull have to do that  There shouldn’t be a dference when it comes to who is who, it should all be the same.” Hull’s CCG only has restrictions for surgery on a patients BMI and does not have a policy in place that restricts surgery for patients who are smokers. A spokesperson for NHS Hull CCG said: “Although we anticipate that the patient’s GP clinician would advise on the range of support in place to help people to give up smoking, NHS Hull CCG does not have a policy that restricts surgery for patients on the grounds of whether they smoke or not.” East Riding CCG , on the other hand, requires patients to go through a non-smoking clinic for a period of six months before NHS funding for surgery can be granted. Paula South, director of quality and governance   lead nurse at ERYCCG, said: “We know patients who smoke or are obese are at increased risk of suffering complications during or after their operation. “In October , the CCG introduced Health Optimisation to improve the health and wellbeing of our residents. For our patients who smoke or have a Body Mass Indexof  or higher, we provide support for a -month period to help them quit smoking or lose weight before any non-urgent surgery. “This helps to make sure our patients are in the best possible health when they go for their operation and able to recover better afterwards. After the -month period, or sooner,they stop smoking or lose the required weight, patients are eligible for referral to surgery. “There are a number of exemptions including patients who need urgent or emergency surgery, they will not have to wait.” Laura has said she will be sending a complaint to the Patient Advise and Liasion Service .

title: uk weather forecast britain faces
story: NewsUK weather forecast: Britain faces ‘Toxic Wednesday’ with -mile Saharan dust plumeSaharan dust plume will bring C weather - the hottest winter day in  years - as well as worrying air pollutionShareCommentsByAlistair Grant:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsForecasters say Wednesday could be the hottest winter day in  years "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain could see its hottest winter day in  years as a -mile wide Saharan dust plume brings C heat - but toxic levels of air pollution have prompted warnings. Parts of the UK will be hotter than Delhi, weather forecasters predict – but “shock to the system” March storms will follow from Saturday, with gusts up to mph. Yesterday a February record of .C was recorded at Trawsgoed, Ceredigion, Wales. Britain is C hotter than average C February maximums and hotter than C New Delhi, India, C Jacksonville, Florida, and C Bermuda. Met Office forecaster Sophie Yeomans said: “Some air has come from the Sahara, with temperatures more than C above average.   “But there’s a change by the weekend with the wetter and windier conditions arriving as the strengthened jetstream brings in weather systems.” Met Office forecaster Dean Hall said: “A stark change is ahead, with later in the week seeing rain and strong winds risking gales of over mph. “The theme of Atlantic systems bringing wet and windy spells looks to remain.” The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “The Atlantic will hit back with stormy spells and gusts of up to mph threatening in early March.”   Ex-BBC and Met Office forecaster John Hammond of weathertrending said: “Early March may bring a shock to the system, with a turbulent, even stormy, few days from March . The start of spring looks a good deal chillier than the end of February.” After Wednesday the Met Office forecast highs tumbling to C by the weekend with bouts of wet and windy conditions from Saturday and through the first half of March, with snow flurries in the North. Dusty air blown , miles from the Sahara is bringing this week’s heat – but also ‘very high’ air pollution on Wednesday with warnings hundreds will die as a result. People with asthma or lung and heart problems, as well as the elderly, were told to reduce exercise in very high pollution areas to reduce health risks, DEFRA guidance said. “Wednesday will be Britain’s worst air pollution episode for a year - since the Beast from the East, DEFRA forecasts show,” said Simon Birkett, director of campaign group Clean Air in London.  “Its a perfect storm of three factors – Saharan dust, pollution from the continent’s power stations, factories and farming fertilisers, and light winds meaning homegrown traffic pollution doesnt disperse. “Studies show hundreds of people will die early this week as a result.” Greenpeace said an extra  people died early as a result of  days’ severe air pollution in March and April , quoting a study published in scientic journal Environment International. , Brits are killed annually by air pollution -  times more than the , who die in road accidents - Department of Health-backed research shows.  The Department for Environment, Food  Rural Affairs said: “Moderate to high levels of air pollution are forecast to persist during Wednesday, with a risk of very high levels in urban centres of northern England. “There is the potential for Saharan dust. There is a mixture of locally generated and continental sources coupled with light winds.” DEFRA guidance for very high air pollution said: “Older people, adults and children with lung problems and adults with heart problems should avoid strenuous physical activity. People with asthma may find they need to use their reliever inhaler. “The general population should reduce physical exertion, especiallyyou experience a cough or sore throat.”

story: NewsMeghan Markle wannabe mum-of- spends £k on plastic surgery to look like idolXochytl Greer, , from Houston, Texas, now feels a real-le princess after undergoing numerous procedures - including a nose jobShareCommentsByJosh Saunders:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video mum-three-spends-k-look-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum-of-three has forked out poundk on plastic surgery to look like Meghan Markle - and claims her daughter confuses the real Duchess for her.Xochytl Greer, , from Houston, Texas, has undergone ious procedures to emulate Meghan, , including having lip filler and a nose job. title: extinct giant tortoise could reproduce
story: NewsExtinct giant tortoise could reproduce with -year-old sperm stored inside herEXCLUSIVE: Biologist and TV host Forrest Galante described the moment he found the long-lost Fernandina Tortoise after a daring expedition to the Galapagos islandShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  FEB News"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA female tortoise, rediscovered more than a century after her species was presumed extinct, could still give birth using sperm she kept inside her since the last time she mated - as long as a HUNDRED years ago. The giant Fernandina Tortoise, which had not been seen since , was found last month on the remote volcanic island of Fernandina in the Galapagos. But with the only other specimen ever found a dead male collected at the turn of the century, news of the historic discovery was muted by the fact that, unless another male is found soon, the species would die out with her. But Forrest Galante, the biologist and Animal Planet presenter who led the expedition, today said the female could still save her species - because of her amazing ability to keep fertile sperm until she needs it. And he said that as the tortoise, now named Fern and aged around , gains weight and becomes healthier now she’s in captivity, she could surprise conservationists by laying eggs using decades-old sperm without the need to find a male suitor.   Speaking to , he said: “Its incredible, but female tortoises are able to withhold viable sperm within them for decades, then produce offspring without having to mate a second time. “Because she’s been under such extreme environmental stress, she’s thin, she’s relatively dehydrated, she wouldn’t have laid eggs because that’s too much of a biological resource for her to expend, and her body would have retain the sperm inside of her. “But now she’s in captivity, eating, drinking, and gaining weight, she could easily produce viable offspring without having to mate a second time. “Nobody knows anything about the Fernandina tortoise because it’s the first one ever found, but given the harshness of the environment and the uniqueness of the animal, it’s certainly possible that she is able to hold viable sperm for  years. “We won’t know until she begins to lay eggs.” The animal was captured during an expedition funding by TV channel Animal Planet for the series Extinct or Alive, which Forrest presents.  He said the trip to the remote island of Fernandina, about  miles off Ecuador’s mainland and featuring the La Cumbre volcano, one of the most active in the world, came after years of meticulous planning. Forrest said: “A couple of things led me to believe there was a chance the Fernandina tortoise wasn’t extinct.In  a man named Ross Tysler found tortoise droppings on a dferent part of the island. “And locals said they might have seen a tortoise up on a clf from the shore. So there were a couple of very small clues. But to me the thing that told me the tortoise could be there was the fact that nobody goes to the island, it’s so remote and such a harsh environment and permission to step foot on the island is next to impossible to obtain.”  Forrest and his team, along with Galapagos National Park Ranger Jeffery Malaga and the director of the Galapagos Conservancy, Washington Tapia, began the expedition with a -hour boat ride from Santa Cruz, the capital of the Galapagos islands. He said: “Once we got there we had to make land, through swells in a small dinghy, and literally hop off of the boat onto the shore, with all of our camping gear. “We then hiked for a day to build camp. There are no trees in the area, it was about  degrees, with heat radiating up from the ground because it’s a volcano, and the equatorial sun beating down on you. The conditions were extremely harsh.” The team began by hiking up to the top of the volcano in order to survey the island and look for possible places where tortoises might be living. Forrest said: “I identied some green spaces, which were incredibly isolated because of the lava flows. I knew getting to each green space would be very slow and very treacherous. “We hiked back down the volcano to camp, slept the night, and on day two started before dawn, hiking for about six hours over the lava fields to the first green patch. “Absolutely amazingly, within just a couple of hours of getting to the green space, we found tortoise scat, then an active bedding site. “By now I’d become so hyper-focused on my mission that for the first time in days I forgot the fact I had massive sunburn and partial heatstroke, and that I was soaking in sweat and everything .About  minutes later, we we spotted her hiding under a bush.   Describing the moment he found the tortoise, Forrest said: “It was an overwhelming sense of excitement and accomplishment, bigger than words can describe really. “This incredible feeling of finding an animal that the world had forgotten about came over me and the rest of the team.” He said the tortoise could have been completely alone, surviving on the patch of habitant encircled by lava flows, for up to  years. Foorest added: “She has been on her own for a very long time, she is over  years old, probably around  judging by her features.  “Whether there has been another animal in that patch in the last century or not I really can’t say.It’s certainly possible that the patch was five or six times the size it is today, and that a recent lava flow wiped out all the animals, and she just got lucky. “It’s also possible that another tortoise could have been there with her for thirty or forty years and then died. Or she could have been completely on her own for a human letime - there’s no way to judge that. Forrest is now turning his attention to finding a male suitor for Fern.  He said: “We spent two more days looking for a male but didn’t find another inidual. “There are several other patches of green space on the island.Because it’s a volcano there are these massive lava flows which a tortoise cannot cross, and which separate these small pockets of habitat.So my guess is there could be other tortoises in these places. “Now the world’s attention has turned to Fern funding is being collected for a future expedition to try to locate a male.  “That would be the best way to keep the species alive. Butwe can’t find one, there’s still hope.We could mate her with another male from another nearby island, so you would have a tortoise which is very genetically close to the Fernandina tortoise and aesthetically identical. “Or she could surprise us by using sperm she’s kept inside her for decades and just start laying eggs. That would be just incredible.”

story: In a general conversation about football , I was asked which one player did I find it hard to play against.My answer was instant . . . Jimmy Bone.Now, my encounter was really brief, as I came on as a substitute for East Fe at Partick Thistle in , a game we were to lose -. In my time on the pitch, his movement was such I hadn’t encountered before, and he gave me “a doing”.Many years later, when he was assistant to Jocky Scott at Dens Park, I asked himhe remembered that game.“I do remember that game very well,” he immediately said.“I had just come back from injury at that time and was really buzzing to be back in the team.“I did give the East Fe central defenders a hard time.”Then, looking straight at me, he concluded: “Don’t worry, I would have given anyone a doing on that day.”After he scored well over  goals for Partick Thistle, others noted his form and he soon earned a move to Norwich, then on to Sheffield United.Celtic took him back to Scotland, but he didn’t appear regularly for the Hoops.In , Arbroath paid around £, to Celtic to bring him to Gayfield and then recouped treble that amount three years later when they sold him to Alex Ferguson’s St Mirren.After four years at Love Street, he had spells with Toronto Blizzard and Hong Kong Rangers before spending two years with Hearts and another stint at Arbroath.Bonemoved into management with Arbroath in that second spell, then took charge of Airdrie, St Mirren, East Fe and Stenhousemuir.In addition to his coaching stint at Dens, he enjoyed similar posts at Ross County, Partick Thistle and Chester City. Other appointments took him abroad to Zambiaand Bidvest Wits .

title: dundee announce pre contract signing of winger todd
story: Dundee have secured the summer signing of Queen of the South midfielder Josh Todd on a pre-contract deal.The -year-old impressed for the Doonhamers in the Championship as well as in their Scottish Cup victory over the Dark Blues last month.And Dens boss Jim McIntyre has moved quickly to secure the former St Mirren man on a two-year deal starting when his contract at Palmerston comes to an end this summer.Todd has scored six goals in  matches this season.Queens manager Gary Naysmith said: “I would like thank Josh for his efforts and contribution since joining the club.#He is a very talented player who has been great for us, it is disappointing to lose someone of his quality but that’s football.#We wouldn’t stand in the way of anyone who has the chance to move to a higher level, so he goes with our best wishes.#He is still with us for a wee while yet and, hopefully, he canfrom injury and play his part in helping us reach the play-offs.”

title: dundee railway station units remain empty because of paying living wage
story: Units at Dundee’s new railway station entrance may still be sitting empty six months after it opened because occupants have been ordered to pay a living wage, it has been suggested.Estate agents Ryden were put in charge of finding tenants for the units inside the new station entrance, which opened last July.However, following an initial flurry of interest in the units – including an offer on the retail block – the facilities are still to find occupants.Neither unit is currently under offer, according to listings on Ryden’s website.This is despite both being prepared by builders for “immediate occupation” to make them lucrative to would-be occupants.It has been suggested in some circles that Dundee City Council’s insistence on occupants of the city’s new Waterfront development paying a “living wage” has put firms off.The council pays its staff wages that align with the Living Wage Foundation’s benchmark.In Scotland, this is currently £ an hour, higher than the National Living Wage of £. that is set for adults over  by the UK Government. vw, px"  One business source told the Tele: “You would have thought the station would have opened with the units occupied.“I think part of the issue is the living wage. If, for example, a big company didn’t pay the living wage but wanted to move into Dundee, it would have to agree to pay it.“That could make things dficult for them as it would set a precedent for their stores where in the UK.”Despite the apparent lack of interest, “discussions with the council about prospective tenants” are ongoing, according to one partner in the estate agency.The Tele understands supermarket chain Sainsbury’s had considered the station’s retail unit, but has opted to open its first city centre “Local” shop on Perth Road.A number of other supermarkets and coffee shop firms approached for comment by the Tele say they have no plans for the units.Bill Marley, a partner with Ryden, said at the time of the station’s opening that the agents were working “closely” with Dundee City Council to market the units.Ryden is also responsible for marketing the full range of units across the £ billion Waterfront project.Dundee City Council was approached for comment ahead of going to press.

title: gordon forrest says dundee united fans vital in championship promotion push
story: Dundee United fans have been told they’re not just appreciated, they’ll be vital as the Championship promotion race reaches its climax.That’s the view of Tangerines assistant boss Gordon Forrest, who admits since ing to Scottish football last month he’s been blown away by the level of support Arabs give their team.Well over , headed for Falkirk on Saturday and, despite a small travelling support expected and the top two in the ision meeting in Dingwall, tonight’s clash with Inverness Caley Thistle at Tannadice will boast the biggest turnout in the second tier.While those kind of crowds can have a positive effect on the opposition, Gordon believes the positives of being the best-supported team in the ision easily outweigh any negatives.“The fans have been absolutely magnicent, particularly in the away games,” said the former Vancouver Whitecaps coach.“When the players are coming out for their warm-up, during the game, you can see the stands are packed. The fans are singing, they’re cheering and it just makes a massive dference for the players.“When we go back to Tannadice the noise levels there have been great. We appreciate it as a club and I know the players do.“When we play against teams they do pick up to their maximum in terms of their performance, they raise their game a little bit but it helps us in that push to pick up the points in the run-in.”Tonight, United will be without defender Freddy Frans after he had to come off with a groin injury at the weekend.He will see a specialist about the problem and, while United are hopeful he will not be out for too long, he has no chance of making tonight or Sunday, when the teamsto Tannadice to battle it out in the Scottish Cup quarter-finals.Rachid Bouhenna came on for Frans then had to go off late on with a facial injury, but could be OK.“Freddy is probably looking at a longer time out. In terms of finer detail and the number of days or weeks it’s hard to say just now,” added Gordon.“With Rachid, there was a lot of blood and a cut on the nose. You’ve got to be careful with that. Hopefully he can be patched up and be in the mix.”

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Disaled workers getting a raw deal new report claims
story: MANY disabled people in Scotland have been ldquofrozen out of work due to their condition, according to research by disability charity Leonard Cheshire.Three out of four said they left their jobs because they had not received the support they needed to fulfil their role, and nearly one out of five who applied for a job in the past five years felt the employer had chosen not to consider them for the post because they had a disability.Kenny Shand from Inverness who found himself in this situation, said: ldquoNot everyone is treated with respect. Whether you have additional support needs or not, the system needs to be more transparent. Workplace adjustments donrsquot need to be expensive ndash they just need to be done.Stuart Robertson, director at Leonard Cheshire in Scotland, said the findings lt the lid on a ldquotough and unwelcoming employment landscape.He said: ldquoMost people with disabilities in  remain frozen out of the world of work. All of us must redouble our efforts to challenge outdated attitudes to disability and accelerate the positive change that enables everyone to thrive in the world of work.The research also suggests more than half of all managers consider the cost of workplace adjustments a barrier to employing people with disabilities.In more promising news, Leonard Cheshirersquos research found a fth of employers say they are more likely to employ someone with a disability.The charity said the latest research shows an increased awareness amongst employers of the UK Governmentrsquos Access to Work scheme giving people grant and other support based on their needs, is up to  percent in  from  percent in .But many recipients are waiting more than three months for their application to be approved and the charity wants government action.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: First phase of 32m refurbishment completed at Inverness school
story: THE first phase of a major refurbishment programme at an Inverness primary school has been completed.Two new classrooms have opened at Smithton Primary, much to the delight of principal teacher Lynne Macdonald who said the new facilities increased opportunities for its  children as well as staff.Pupils have also got a new a multiuse games area.ldquoItrsquos made a huge dference, she said.ldquoIt gives us a lot more space and just little things like having blackout blinds on sunny days and having all the children in seats at the same height really helps.The pound. million refurbishment project to address the schoolrsquos current and future capacity needs began last April.Once completed, it will see a total of five additional classrooms created along with two support needs rooms, a dedicated space for senior pupils and an extended gym hall.Local councillor Trish Robertson said it was excellent to see the project start to take shape.ldquoThe expansion was badly needed and having the extra space must be better for the children, she said. ldquoIrsquom really pleased itrsquos gone up so quickly.Iain MacDonald, special works manager for Morgan Sindall, which is carrying out the renovation work, said construction was currently on track for completion by September.ldquoThe most important thing for us has been not to interrupt the daily activity of the school, he said.ldquoBut another big thing is giving the kids a good experience of construction ndash therersquos a perception that construction is about the trades but therersquos so much more to get involved in.Miss Macdonald added: ldquoThe workers have been great. They always make sure they receive any deliveries before am which really helps and means the construction isnrsquot impacting the children. Thatrsquos the most important thing.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Funding blow to Highland food banks charity
story: North-based charity Blythswood Care has issued a public appeal for more donations after it lost an annual pound, recycling grant from Highland Council in the recent local authority budget.The charity which has one of the largest networks of food banks in the Highlands handles around  tonnes of clothing donations a year at its Evanton depot of which more than  per cent was reused or recycled.Previously the council financially supported the recycling work and some local authority properties already host textile banks for taking unwanted clothing deposits but this year withdrew support.The council had to plug an almost pound million financial hole in its budget amid shrinking government grants for core services, the moves was called a ldquobody blow by operations manager Ian Matheson who admitted the loss of the recycling grant is not a complete surprise.ldquoWe recognise that the Council has been faced with hard decisions. Wersquove enjoyed a mutually beneficial partnership with Highland Council for over  years and we really appreciate that, he said.ldquoTheir support has enabled us to develop our re-use and recycling activities, reducing waste, providing local employment and raising support for projects such as Blythswoodrsquos Highland Food Bank.ldquoDonations of clothing, bric-a-brac and quality furniture from the general public are going to be more important to us than ever as we aim to continue this aspect of our work despite the loss of this grant.The organisation processes more than , tonnes of donations a year at its Evanton depot, producing goods for its charity shops and selling on to processors in other parts of the country.Mr Matheson said ldquoWe have to constantly review all that we do and consider what efficiencies we can make. You can help us now by giving our shops your custom and donations.ldquoAll donations will be gratefully received so we can have continuity of employment ndash because this is about jobs too ndash as well as maintain service provision.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have had very positive discussions with Blythswood and these are ongoing about how we can possibly work together in the future.Blythswood welcomes donations of textiles, footwear, bric-a-brac, small electrical goods, books and good quality furniture.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Stonework to be refurbished at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Stonework at the Academy Street entrance to Invernesss Victorian Market is to be refurbished at a cost of pound,.The sum will be coveredby grants from the Academy Street Townscape Heritage Trust andInverness Common Good Fund .The decision to push ahead with the project will mean a delay to other planned mechanical and electrical works, alongwith the installation ofnew doors at the market.pound, remains allocated towards the upgrading of shopfronts at the market, including new lighting and flooring.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Sugars night set to be sweet for Highland Hospice
story: AN evening of fun, quality entertainment and good food has been promised by an Inverness man who is raising money for the Highland Hospice.Alastair Kennedy, communications director at Global Energy Group and chairman of Nigg Skills Academy, is calling on local businesses to try and help with his fundraising for this yearrsquos Strictly Inverness dancing competition.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom hoping that the business community will support this amazing cause as they have done in the past.Known to his friends as Sugar, Mr Kennedy will be hosting a dinner called Sugarrsquos Strictly Big Night at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on April .The black tie tartan event will consist of live music from local band Torridon as well as an auction, quiz and a raffle, with all proceeds going to the hospice.Mr Kennedy is reaching out to the local business community to come along and support the event so he can raise as much money as possible.The director of Ross County Football Club is well known for his enjoyable hosting of hospitality at their home matches over the past  years, and thinks he has the the expertise and dry sense of humour to host another entertaining and enjoyable evening for all.As the oldest ever competitor in Strictly Inverness, Mr Kennedy was inspired to get involved in this yearrsquos event after sadly losing his mother to cancer in . She spent her final days in the hospice.ldquoTheir facilities and the care they provided for my mum was just so wonderful and considerate, he said.ldquoThey looked after her so well in her last days with us. I said at the time that I must, at some point in the future, do something to raise much-needed funds for the hospice, and with it being their th Strictly anniversary year, I just thought maybe now is the time.ldquoThere are lots of couples competing for the Strictly Inverness title and there is already great camaraderie being built up between us all.ldquoThis is not so much about winning, itrsquos more about raising money for this most worthy cause and everyone is working so hard not just in dance training, but in raising money by whatever means. I am hoping my business connections will assist me in being able to create a great night, but also raise as much money as possible for the hospice.Tables cost pound for  people and anyone interested should contact Mr Kennedy via Global Energy Group.Strictly Inverness also raises money for Inverness Ice Centre, which hosts the showdown from May .Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: mcinnes looks for home comforts
story: Aberdeen may have equalled a club record winning streak on the road but boss Derek McInnes has called for an end to their Pittodrie slump.The - win at St Johnstone was the Reds’ seventh straight victory away from home in all competitions.It matched the previous club best set in  and .The Dons also boast the best away form in the Scottish Premiership with  points from  games.Yet at Pittodrie the Dons have taken just two points from the last possible .McInnes has called for that slump to end tomorrow when hosting Hamilton.He said: “It is great we have managed to equal that club record.“Especially when you think of some of the great Aberdeen teams there have been in the history at our club.“It says a lot about our players and their intent on the road.“We have always been a decent away team and always been quite strong at Pittodrie.“Since the turn of the year it has not been as free-flowing and straightforward at home.“But at St Johnstone it was illustrated when we play at tempo and have space to work in that we are a good team.“That has been the key to the away games.“However, you have to work for that space.“What we have to do against Hamilton is generate the same speed and intensity we did at St Johnstone.“But also have the calmness and composure when teams come up and sit off us.”Relegation-battling Hamilton will arrive at Pittodrie on the back of a - hammering from Rangers on Sunday.Aberdeen remained five points behind second-placed Rangers with the victory over St Johnstone in Perth.McInnes was pleased with the Reds’ performance and result after the disappointment of dropping points to bottom side St Mirren in the previous match.He said: “That was another big victory for us.“When you start to run out of league games you want to make sure that you maximise everything you have from your season.“It was important we had to make up for last week against St Mirren.“I was really pleased.“Last week I was frustrated as we felt we squandered two points at home.“We tried to make up for that by getting the three points back at St Johnstone.“I watched St Johnstone’s game against Rangers and they were very good.“We knew the dficulty of the task in coming to Perth.“They started better than us as I thought we were a wee bit limp in one or two of the challenges.“It was important that we quicken our minds up and played the game at the level we needed to play it at.“Once we got the first goal we were in charge of the game.“St Johnstone had to change as Tommytries to go -- and we dealt with that.“it allowed us more space to work and we were just kicking ourselves that we hadn’t got that second goal before it came.“Then Shinnie scored it with a very good finish off his left side, his natural side.“From then on in we looked like a very experienced team and managed the game.“A clean sheet and three points and a very good performance, I couldn’t ask for any more.”

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayrshire hospice marks 30th birthday
story: NewsAyrshire Hospice marks th birthday as staff and volunteers reflect on three decades of serviceThe milestone birthday has been marked with a series of events and celebrations.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor  years it has touched the lives of thousands in Ayrshire and far beyond. Its mission  To enrich the remaining days of those facing le-limiting illness. The work of the Ayrshire Hospice, irreplaceable since February , has formed part of the region’s fabric over three decades. But at pound, per day to fund bosses admit they owe their biggest debt to the public. Reflecting on the landmark birthday, chief executive Mandy Yule said: “Our message to the wonderful people of Ayrshire is ‘thank you’. “We wouldn’t be able to deliver the level of care we doit wasn’t for their support. “We have an incredible group of volunteers and fundraisers across Ayrshire, some of whom have given their time for over  years, and without the fundraising efforts the hospice wouldn’t be here.” Since opening its doors on Racecourse Road the base has become a centre of care, comfort, compassion and dignity to more than , patients.  But its true origins go back even further to a group of hard-working volunteers who set up their own trust in . Their goal was to raise the necessary funds to open a hospice in Ayrshire. After as initial target of pound, was met within  months the next task of finding a suitable location threw up Racecourse Road. Building work began in  and, with it, the hospice service was launched with the appointment of two home care nurses. From its earliest days fundraising has served the heart of the hospice. And it is that invaluable support that the hospice – which has almost  staff and volunteers – is recognising during its th year.   Mandy said: “Because of their efforts we have access to some of the best palliative care treatments available, allowing us to give our patients comfort and quality of le. “We have been privileged to give thousands of patients and their families the care and support they need, both at the hospice itself or wherever they have lived in Ayrshire, over the last  years and we take great pride in that”. To help mark the anniversary a special memory tree has been created giving the opportunity to leave reflections and memories of the hospice. Mandy said: “We never take the compassionate and continued support of the hospice by the people of Ayrshire for granted. “The memory tree gives people the chance to leave their own memories or thoughts about the hospice and be part of our celebration.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: jury asked convict ayr broadcaster
story: NewsJury asked to convict Ayr broadcaster Bryce Curdy on girl rape chargeHis defence claims evidence against him "doesnt stack up"ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsThe trial is taking place at the High Court in Glasgow "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA PROSECUTOR has urged a jury to convict broadcaster Bryce Curdy of raping a -year-old girl in the South of France. Liam Ewing told jurors: “You have heard how the girl described screaming as he raped her.” He added: “I ask you to examine the evidence. She goes into a lot of detail about what happened to her. I invite you toa guilty verdict.” The alleged victim, who is now , claimed that Curdy, , from Ayr, raped her three times. She alleged that on each occasion he whispered to her afterwards” If you tell anyone I will kill you and your mum.” Curdy, who is on trial at the High Court in Glasgow, denies raping her on ious occasions between April  and August , , at a house in the South of France. Mr Ewing told the jury that the Crown is relying on testimony from the girls mother, who is , to corroborate the rape. She alleges that Curdy also raped her in August  in the South of France. The mothers allegation, which he denies, is not before the jury. Under Scots Law alleged crimes against children committed in another country can be prosecuted here, but not those against adults. The mother claimed that after having consensual sex with her, Curdy went on to rape her. Defence counsel Lorenzo Alonzi told the jury: “If you apply the law, you will find that the correct verdict in this case is acquittal.” Mr Alonzi said in his closing speech that there was absolutely no independent evidence in this case – only the allegations of the girl and her mother. He went on: “There is no DNA evidence, there is no torn clothing, there is no medical evidence and no witnesses who heard screams. “The idea that there was this monstrous threat to kill her and her mum, it doesnt stack up.” Curdy claimed that the two woman made up the allegations about him after he demanded theof his pound, gold and diamond Rolex watch. The trial before judge Johanna Johnston QC continues.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSex crimeGlasgowAyrCourtsJusticeAyr News
