title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: Rosemary Goring  Now is the time for the Catholic Church   s own Reformation
story: For this book Martel has conducted more than , interviews in the Vatican City in Rome, and across the world. He has spoken to priests, cardinals, bishops, monsignors, papal ambassadors, seminarians and the Swiss Guard. His conclusion, which will shock some and come as no surprise to others, is that about  per cent of the clergy in the Vatican state are gay. In other words, the HQ of a church that will not bless same-sex relationships, and forbids its clergy to have sex lives, is riddled with hyprocisy at its very core.Of these  per cent, Martel writes, some are celibate or in denial, others are living with their partners, or resort to prostitutes. A rule of thumb is that the more vehemently a cleric condemns homosexuality, the more likely he is to be in the closet himself. Hence the behaviour of the Colombian cardinal, Alfonso Lopez Trujillo. He was in the vanguard of the churchrsquos mission to prevent gay marriage. As the dire consequences of the Aids epidemic became clear, contrary to commonsense and compassion, he refused to encourage the use of condoms. Here was someone eager to be seen to uphold traditional values. Yet Martel claims that Trujillo, who died in , used male prostitutes.There are examples closer to home, among them the late Cardinal Keith OrsquoBrien, who pursued a similarly denunciatory anti-gay agenda, despite his own homosexuality and predatory behaviour. In fact, it doesnrsquot matter where you look. Throughout the Catholic churchrsquos parishes, globally and locally, there has been the mother of all cover-ups, not just in the buttoned-up past, but right now, here, today.You could say the church has been built on lies: countless men forced to hide who they really are, or to seek refuge in an all-male environment where they could find illicit love behind closed doors. Those clergy who were straight must have found themselves in a bewildering labyrinth of duplicity. That such depths of deceit have been allowed to thrive says all you need to know about the controlling power of those at the heart of the church.Martel believes that Pope Francis has earned enemies by adopting a very untypical approach. ldquoWho am I to judge  he replied, when askedhe condemned homosexuals, thereby loosening the ground beneath the feet of those in the Holy See who donrsquot want their secrets aired, or their way of le altered.The revelation of such widespread double standards is an echo of the medieval churchrsquos calamitous abuse of power and wealth. Out of it has sprung a culture where bullying, intimidation and blackmail have flourished. Andthat has been going on in this sphere, you can be sure it will have spilled over into every other part of the churchrsquos affairs.In the wake of the revelation of child abuse on a grand scale in the church, you begin to see why hiding the truth was the default position. This is not to make a link between homosexuality and child abuse but to see why the ecclesiastical authorities were so quick, and adept, at making the problem disappear. In avoiding scandal, they were intent on protecting their own rather than those who had been so grievously harmed.With evidence of institutionalised deception of the extent Martel claims, the church brings shame on itself: not for the numbers of priests who are gay, but for the willingness to lie about it, and to break vows, and the spirit of vocation, to an extent that will appall devout parishioners.Now is the time for the Catholic Churchrsquos own Reformation. No-one can any longer doubt that the le expected of a Catholic priest is unhealthy. And since there is no biblical injunction on him to be celibate, why can this not be changed  Already the church is embracing married Anglican vicars in flight from the ordination of women. Why not allow Catholic clergy the same right to open relationships, whether they be gay or straight Until the double-speak on which the modern church stands is addressed, there is no hope of winning back the faithful who have lost all trust and respect in this once revered institution. Obliging men to profess one thing while being another, is psychological torment. The denial of clergyrsquos humanity and self-expression is as cruel as anything the Inquisition devised. If the Vatican could bring itself to accept homosexuality, and gay marriage, and a non-celibate priesthood, it would be a truly Christian act.Read more: Cardinal Keith OBrien asked for forgiveness

title: Marianne Taylor  Last chance for Mundell to put country before party
story: The majority of these demands are perfunctory, of course, made in the knowledge and expectation that they will be ignored by the target, while playing well with the initiatorrsquos supporters.The craziness of the last few months has precipitated a flurry of genuine and warranted resignation demands, however, which under normal political circumstances would have resulted in multiple ministerial heads rolling in any other era the Prime Minister would have been forced out long ago.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysAnother case in point is Scottish Secretary David Mundell, whose stubborn insistence on being ineffectual in the face of the biggest crisis this country has faced in generations is matched only by that of Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Mundellrsquos wan smiles and empty words about doing the best for Scotland as the Government he is a member of readies itself to push us off the no-deal Brexit clf, is as astonishing as it is appalling. He, too, should have gone months ago, not least over the manner in which his party has arrogantly steamrollered over the views and interests of the country he supposedly represents.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitRemarkably still in post, Mr Mundell now has one last chance to make a meaningful contribution to the ridiculous and dangerous situation the Westminster parliament has created for itself. The SNP is right to call for Mr Mundell to show some mettle and make clear that he will not serve in a Government that is willing to take us out of the European Union without a deal, a situation that would put the already fragile Scottish economy on the road to ruin. As the Scottish Secretary is well aware, businesses will fail, jobs will be lost and real people will suffer the sort of real hardships that will be dficult to recover from.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has written to Mr Mundell, laying out the gravity of the situation and calling on him to back growing cross-party demands to halt the Brexit process by extending Article  and making clear to his boss, Theresa May, that he will resign unless she faces up the extremists in her party and takes no-deal off the table.At this critical juncture, the least that the people of Scotland deserve from the man who represents them at Cabinet level is honesty about where his loyalties lie: will he put country or party first  Mr Mundell, it really is that simple.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitOf course, Mr Blackfordrsquos letter also highlights the bleakness of the dilemma facing the SNP. If Mrs May gets her way and Parliament is faced with a last-minute binary choice between her terrible deal - which deprives us of the key benefits being in the EU - and an even more catastrophic no-deal, it leaves the party in a dficult position. How should Nicola Sturgeon instruct her MPs to vote in this scenario  Backing Mrs Mayrsquos ldquomy way or the highway deal would be criticised by many as a U-turn of epic proportions and a sign of weakness. Not voting for it, and thus facilitating a no-deal Brexit, would likely be viewed by many voters as unforgivable, leaving the party open to allegations that this is the outcome it has been secretly hoping for all along, in order to boost support for independence.Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues will be hoping the growing number of Tory ministers and backbench MPs ndash including Cabinet secretaries Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke - poised to revolt against their leader should she refuse to rule out a no-deal Brexit, will come to their rescue in the frantic days and weeks to come.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysThe emergence of the The Independent Groupmay also end up helping the SNPrsquos predicament, at least in the short term. Formed last week when eight MPs resigned from Labour unhappy at Mr Corbynrsquos disastrous leadership, it did not initially appear to be an important development. But when three Tory MPs also resigned and joined up, using the moment to launch a blistering attack on Mrs Mayrsquos disastrous Brexit strategy and their partyrsquos lurch to the right, it started to feel more signicant.What binds these MPs from dferent sides of the House of Commons is dismay at the drt of both parties to the extremities. And despite not being a proper party - yet - or having any actual policiesit seems many voters quite like what they see.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitMomentum has grown over the weekend, with polls already putting the group on  per cent, just one behind the increasingly irrelevant Lib Dems.Many are asking whether TIG has a future. Surely, however, whatrsquos most important is the future of the country, andthis new movement serves only to facilitate the halting of Article , so that a new road out of the current mess can be found, then it will already have done more for the UK than Mr Corbyn. Or indeed Mr Mundell for that matter.

title: tv-review-is-the-new-bbc-scotland-channel-magic-or-mince
story: Three, two, one went the countdown and there was Chvrches singer Lauren Mayberry singing a number which would not be out of place in the next Bond film. Programming proper began, oddly, with A Night at the Theatrehosted by Iain Stirling, the voice of Love Island, the ITV reality show infamous for the thickness of the contestants and the thinness of the sheets under which they have sex on camera.ChVrches and SSO open new channelIf you know who Stirling is then you are probably the target demographic of the new channel. If not, then you, like me, are part of the fuddy duddy majority, those who sit down to an eveningrsquos viewing as we would a meal, consuming one programme after another till wersquove had enough, or the wine runs out. The Love Island lot are the take away set, snacking on ldquocontent" whenever and wherever they choose, either on social media or iPlayer.Whatever your age, the only thing worse than A Night at the Theatre would have been an afternoon in surgery. Tired, unfunny and peppered with audience participation games, it made The Good Old Days look like Sinatra at the Sands.        name : ballot,target: ballot_,params:.pushSTV, which closed down last year after failing to attract enough viewers, was run on pound million a year, bawbees in TV terms. BBC Scotland has pound million, but from that sum, which would buy three and a bit hours of Netflixrsquos The Crown, it has to fund  hours of programmes. Getting Hitched Asian Stylegave a hint of how the new channel would make the pennies stretch. A documentary about wedding planners Saffron Events, it had good talkersand some mild drama , but it was baggy and repetitive, just about it making it to an hourrsquos worth of material. There are two more parts to come. Is there really more to say YouTube star on new seriesThe Peoplersquos Newsgave people the chance to, er, give us their views on the news. There was one official taxi driver on it, and lots of people who could have been taxi drivers so in love were they with the sound of their own voices. A little bit Gogglebox, and accompanied by a head-splitting soundtrack, the hipsters at Channel  news will be kicking themselves they did not think of this first.At last, a proper event for event TV: the first episode of the final series of Still Game . With the dreadful timing of the Scotland football squad, the gang have found their form again when it no longer matters. The story about Jack and Victor entering the YouTube age was about as original as jokes about cat videos, but it left plenty of room for what SG does best: daftness laced with cyanide-strength sarcasm Burnistoun Tunes Inwas patchy, but some of the old stuff still works a treat. The nightrsquos final offering was the brilliant documentary Nae Pasaran , about a boycott by Scots engineers that curbed Pinochetrsquos bombing of his own people. Running it earlier would have given the channel a stamp of quality and seriousness, which it needed.Tutti Frutti is backLast night was supposed to be about the thrill of the new,there is such a thing any more in a multichannel world, yet there was something familiar about the evening. It took a while to pin down, then it came to me. The widely-trailedof favourite shows that inevitably struggled to live up to expectations, lots of familiar faces, a whf of prissiness. Yes, it was Hogmanay TV, but on a Sunday in February. BBC Scotland director Donalda MacKinnon has said the channelrsquos goal is "success over time". Consider the clock ticking.

title: oscars-olivia-colman-wins-best-actress-for-the-favourite
story: The star of The Favourite triumphed over The Wersquos Close, as well as Lady Gaga, Melissa McCarthy and Yalitza Aparicio for an unexpected win at the ceremony, where Green Book was named best picture.Colman was visibly shocked as her name was called and was helped to her feet by her husband Ed Sinclair and co-star Emma Stone, who planted a kiss on her cheek.Taking to the stage, she said: ldquoItrsquos genuinely quite stressful. This is hilarious. I got an Oscar!ldquoOK, I have to thank lots of people. If, by the way, I forget anybody Irsquom going to find you later and Irsquom going to give you all a massive snog and Irsquom really sorryImight forget now."Any little girl thats practicing her speech on the telly, you never know."Congratulations to @TheAcademy winner for Best Actress Olivia Colman. #Oscars #TheFavourite pic hNphloHmdash The FavouriteFebruary , Payingtribute to her director Yorgos Lanthimos as well as Stone and fellow co-star Rachel Weisz, she added: ldquoYorgos, my best director and the best film, and with Emma and Rachel, the two loveliest women in the world to fall in love with, and to go to work with every day, I mean, you can imagine, it wasnrsquot a hardship.ldquoAnd to be in this category with these extraordinary women, and Glenn Closehellip yoursquove been my idol for so long and this is not how I wanted it to be and I think yoursquore amazing and I love you very much.She added that she hoped her children were watching and said: ldquoIf yoursquore not, then, well done, but I sort of hope you are. This is not going to happen again.ldquoAnd any little girl who is practising their speech on the telly, you never know. I used to work as a cleaner and I loved that job, I did spend quite a lot of my time imagining this.Green Book won the biggest prize of the night as the surprise winner of best picture, a category largely expected to go to Roma.The film about a black jazz musician and a white driver travelling through the segregated US deep south also won the best supporting actor Oscar for Mahershala Ali, as well as best original screenplay.Rami Malek was named best actor for his role as Freddie Mercury in the Queen biopic Bohemian Rhapsody and planted a passionate kiss on the lips of his girlfriend and co-star Lucy Boynton before making his way to the stage.Regina King took the best supporting actress prize for her role in If Beale Street Could talk, leading to the most erse group of acting winners in the history of the Oscars.Shallow from A Star Is Born was named best original song and Lady Gaga addressed her director and co-star Bradley Cooper as she collected the gong, saying: ldquoBradley, there is not a single person who could have sang this song with me but you. Thank you for believing in me.ldquoIf you are at home sitting on your couch and watching this now, all I can say is this is hard work. Men And A Lady #################################### pic oSCXtPTfmdash Mark RonsonFebruary , ldquoIrsquove worked hard for a long time. This is not about winning, what itrsquos about is not giving up. If you have a dream fight for it.ldquoItrsquos not about how many times you are rejected and how many times you fall down, itrsquos how many times you stand up and keep going.Cooper and Gaga also performed the song at the ceremony, with the pair looking intently into each otherrsquos eyes during the duet before Cooper sat next to her at the piano.History was made earlier in the night when Ruth Carter became the first black winner to collect the best costume design prize, while Hannah Beachler became the first black winner of the production design gong, both for their work on Black Panther.The Marvel superhero movie was also recognised for its original score."As artists, our job is to look where others dont.This responsibility becomes much more important in times when we are being encouraged to look away.Muchas gracias a Libo. Muchas gracias a mi familia.Muchas gracias a Meacutexico."-Alfonso Cuaroacuten#Oscarsmdash Netflix FilmFebruary , The black-and-white, Spanish-language film Roma won three prizes, collecting the best director prize for Alfonso Cuaron, best cinematography, also for Cuaron, and best foreign language film.Bohemian Rhapsody was the most awarded film at the ceremony, with prizes for Malek, film editing, sound mixing and sound editing.

title: tony-blair-brexit-is-boosting-the-case-for-independence
story: The former Labour Prime Minister said it was ldquoabsolutely bloody obvious to him thatScotland were wrenched out the EU against its will it would help the Yes movement.ldquoIt doesnrsquot mean to say I agree with it, but itrsquos bound to have an impact, he said.In an interview with Holyrood magazine, Mr Blair also said that Scotland might be independent alreadyhis government hadnrsquot introduced devolution  years ago.He said the creation of a Scottish Parliament provided an ldquoalternative to independence and thatit didnrsquot exist, the UK might have broken up instead.:Labour failed in Scotland because it gave up the middle ground says Tony BlairAsked whether he understood why Scotland had voted so dferently from the rest of the UK in the EU referendum, he said: ldquoYes, because I think the degree to which this was driven by a sense of English nationalism, itrsquos obviously going to be more powerful in England than Scotland, and also because I think Scotland is quite comfortable with a European identity.He acknowledged Brexit may have made independence more likely.ldquoIrsquom not saying it will happen, because I still think there are very strong arguments against it, and obviously Irsquom not in favour of it, even after Brexit,we do Brexit.ldquoBut you know, I think when I said this before people criticised it, but it seems to me absolutely bloody obvious,Scotland is in favour of staying in Europe, and you wrench the UK out of Europe, then yep, people who are arguing for independence are going to have another dimension to their argument.ldquoIt doesnrsquot mean to say I agree with it, but itrsquos bound to have an impact.ldquoThe thing thatrsquos most frustrating to me about politics today is that wersquore not arguing about the right thing. Wersquore arguing about national identity, when it really isnrsquot the answer to anything, it really isnrsquot.Scotland voted - Remain in , while the UK as a whole voted - Leave.Mr Blair also admitted that he had over-estimated the power of devolution to dampen calls for independence, and wished Scotland and the UK had stayed ldquomore culturally aligned.Mr Blairrsquos former shadow Scottish Secretary George Robertson famously said in the s that devolution would kill Nationalism ldquostone dead.:Keith Brown: Scottish independence offers opposite of Brexit chaosMr Blair told Holyrood: ldquoUltimately, I think we overestimated, for sure, the degree to which devolution would quash independence, thatrsquos correct hellip But I think were it not for Brexit now, probably the mood in Scotland would be less in favour of independence than for some time.He added: ldquoI thinkI had any regret, I would have looked at more ways to keep Scotland and the UK feeling more culturally aligned.ldquoBut having said that, I think people forget that there was a huge amount of pressure for devolution as an alternative to independence andwe hadnrsquot offered that alternative, you might have had an independent Scotland by now.Deputy SNP leader Keith Brown said: "Make no mistake, Scotland having some powers has been good for Scotland. However today the debate is now fundamentally dferent from what was asked in ."The foundations of Westminster politics are crumbling, with Labour and the Tories choosing to ignore Scotlandrsquos voice and disregard the will of our Parliament, as they fixate themselves on bitter party infighting."Itrsquos clear that the case for independence is more compelling than ever. While Brexit offers small minded isolationism, independence is about Scotland taking its place on the global stage as an equal partner.

title: brexit-deal-within-our-grasp-claims-theresa-may-as-she-sets-her-face-against-extending-article-50
story: Her comments came just moments after Donald Tusk described extending the Article  process as a ldquorational solution to the current UK-EU impasse, warning that the only alternativeMPs could not agree a deal, was "a chaotic Brexit".The European Council President revealed he had discussed the legal and procedural process for extending the withdrawal talks when he met the Prime Minister in Egypt yesterday.Read more:Tony Blair: Brexit is boosting the case for independenceEU officials are said to be considering the option of a delay to exit day not just for a few months as some UK ministers have suggested but until  so that more talks can eliminate the need for the contentious Irish backstop.Pressure is mounting at Westminster from within and outwith the Conservative Party and, indeed, from within the Government itself, for Mrs May to delay withdrawal as MPs prepare to vote for such a proposition tabled in a binding amendment to Wednesdayrsquos debate in the Commons by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper.But, speaking during a press conference at the EU-Arab summit in Sharm el-Sheikh, the PM insisted extending Article  would not address the issues facing Britain over its departure from the EU.ldquoA delay in this process does not deliver a decision in Parliament, it doesnrsquot deliver a deal what it does is precisely what the word says, declared Mrs May, who has had a raft of meetings at the Red Sea resort, including with Germanyrsquos Angela Merkel, Irelandrsquos Leo Varadkar and the European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker.Read more:She told journalists: ldquoI have a real sense from the meetings I have had here, conversations I have had with EU leaders in recent dayshellipwe can achieve that deal. Itrsquos within our grasp to leave with a deal on March  and thatrsquos where all our energies are going to be focused.The PM, who has put off having a meaningful vote this week but promised one by March , admitted there was ldquostill more work to do.But she noted: ldquoWhat I have sensed in all of my conversations with my fellow leaders both here in Sharm el-Sheikh and in recent days is a real determination to find a way through, which allows the UK to leave the EU in a smooth and orderly way with a deal.AskedCabinet ministers Amber Rudd, Greg Clark and David Gauke, who have suggested they could back Ms Cooperrsquos amendment, would have to resignthey did so, Mrs May brushed aside the question.She said: ldquoFirst of all, we have not laid the motion for Wednesday yet, we have not had amendments to that motion, we donrsquot know what amendments are going to be selected for debate.The PM confirmed she would be giving MPs an update on the Brexit talks tomorrow, saying she would tell them: ldquoWe will be making clear we have been making progress, we have had positive and constructive discussions. When we next bring the meaningful vote, itrsquos important people focus on whether we want to deliver on the result of the referendum and do that in a smooth and orderly way by leaving with a deal.Stephen Barclay, the Brexit Secretary, and Geoffrey Cox, the Attorney General, will be back in Brussels tomorrow for more talks with EU officials.The three Cabinet ministers wrote in a joint article at the weekend: "If there is no breakthrough in the coming week, the balance of opinion in Parliament is clear: that it would be better to seek to extend Article  and delay our date of departure rather than crash out of the European Union on March .They added: "It is time that many of our Conservative parliamentary colleagues in the ERG recognised that Parliament will stop a disastrous no-deal Brexit on March . If that happens, they will have no one to blame but themselves for delaying Brexit."Responding to Mrs Mayrsquos latest remarks, Labourrsquos Jo Stevens for the pro-EU Best for Britain campaign said: ldquoFrom the Prime Minister that brought us Brexit means Brexit, Maybot is now claiming that any delay is a delay.ldquoWhile the tectonic plates are shting on Brexit, the Prime Minister continues to have her fingers in her ears. It is shameful that May is holding the country to ransom by toying with a clf-edge Brexit.She added: ldquoItrsquos time for the Government to do the right thing and put the country first. The people want their voice back on Brexit.

title: bitter-legacy-of-miners-strike-sees-just-two-ex-cops-speak-in-public-to-inquiry
story: The low-turnout, a sign of the lasting bitterness around the dispute, is revealed in the interim report of the independent review, which also said its final findings would be delayed from June to August.The atmosphere at public hearings was ldquonot necessarily conducive for retired police officers to share their experience and recollections, it admitted.The situation has forced the review to rely on written evidence and private meetings with former officers instead.:Independent review ordered into policing during the s miners strikeEncouraged by the Retired Police Officers Association Scotland, some retired senior officers directly involved in policing the strike came forward, with a further meeting due this month.The investigation was set up under Solicitor Advocate John Scott QC last June to report on the impact of police tactics during the strike of  and .The period remains infamous for heavy-handed police action against pickets as Tory PM Margaret Thatcher fought the National Union of Mineworkers led by Arthur Scargill.The reviewrsquos interim report said  people attended eight public meetings late last year in Ayrshire, Clackmannanshire, Fe, Lanarkshire, Midlothian, Stirlingshire and West Lothian.It said: ldquoWe heard powerful and moving testimony from iniduals and their families who had been very badly affected by the strike, especially those who were arrested, charged, prosecuted, convicted and sentenced.ldquoMany lost their jobs, with their employers appearing to take a policy decision to dismiss regardless of the gravity of the allegation or the penalty imposed.ldquoSome of these men secured employment where, sometimes quickly but sometimes only after years. Some, especially because of having to declare their conviction, were unable to find other jobs. For some iniduals and their families, the lasting damage was obvious.It added: ldquoAt these meetings, perhaps unsurprisingly, very few speakers identied themselves as retired police officers although two speakers did so, and their contributions assisted in addressing some of the issues which recurred as themes at all of the meetings.:Review of miners strike policing calls for evidenceThe review also took more than  written submissions, including from miners and officers.SNP Justice Secretary Humza Yousaf, who agreed to a short extension to allow the review to write up its findings, said: ldquoScotland is leading the way in ensuring the experiences of those affected by the policing of the dispute in the s are properly heard and understood."I welcome the interim report and in particular the positive engagement undertaken with key iniduals, representative organisations and those employed in the mining industry and police at the time, their wider families and communities.ldquoA final report, setting out lessons learnt and making recommendations for any other action required, will follow at the end of the summer and be made publicly available.ldquoIt is important that we recognise the generous contributions made to the review by those who were affected. I want this review to bring openness, understanding and a degree of closure to all those involved.Mr Scott added: ldquoWhen we started our work on this important review, we decided that we should seek out as much direct evidence as possible from those who were involved in, and affected by, the minersrsquo strike.":Minersrsquo strike call is sheer opportunismLabour MSP Neil Findlay, whose campaigning helped secure the review, said: ldquoMining communities across Britain suffered at the hands of politicised and often brutal policing as Margaret Thatcher and her Tory Government used the power of the state to crush working people.ldquoThe review of these convictions should consider pardons to ensure those who were wrongly convicted finally get justice."GreenMSP John Finnie MSP added: ldquoTherersquos a clear link between the concerns being addressed by this group and the ongoing disquiet about UK undercover police officers who spied on countless political campaigns, stealing citizensrsquo identities along the way.ldquoI believe the Scottish Government should take a similar approach with those matters and instigate a public inquiry into historic UK undercover policing in Scotland, similar to the Pitchford Inquiry in England and Wales, and I urge Mr Yousaf to do so urgently.

title: nessie-is-face-of-new-quintessentially-british-10p
story: But visitors looking for the Loch Ness Monster will soon be better off scanning through the change in their pockets and purses after Nessie was picked to adorn the latest range of  pence pieces from the Royal Mint.The mythical lake-dwelling beast heads up Scotlands representation on a new collection of coinage due to go into circulation this year, featuring an A to Z of British icons from the Angel of the North in Newcastle to Zebra crossings.Nessie was picked due to her popularity both at home an abroad, and represents the letter L.:Royal Mint produces pound coin to mark year Queen became longest-reigning monarch#While the collection - dubbed the Great British Coin Hunt- covers the whole alphabet, the only other Scottish entrant to make the list is a raincoat.Fittingly, for a country where a days rain is never far away, Scottish inventor Charles Mackintoshs rainwear invention will also appear on the coins, representing the letter M.M is for MackintoshMackintosh first created the waterproof overcoat in  and it has become standard apparel for those venturing out in wet climes during the century and a half since.First launched in , the collection has proved incredibly popular amongst the British public but the coins have only had limited circulation.Now an additional . million coins will soon be released to the public, making the chances of bagging a Nessie much more likely.Each have been eagerly snapped up by collectors, with a Loch Ness Monster coin currently worth around pound on online marketplaces, while the Mackintosh is worth pound.Uncirculated versions of the designs are also available to purchase from The Royal Mint website.Nicola Howell, Director of Consumer Business at The Royal Mint said ldquoThese  inidually designed coins, each with a quintessentially British subject, is the first ever commemorative range struck on a  pence piece."It will be one of the most limited issue coin designs for  to be released into circulation, so to complete the collection we also have an exclusively designed  A to Z collector album.:Royal Mint appoints first female boss in over , years#Away from Scotland, some of the UKrsquos most important scientic and technological achievements have also been included in the collection ndash W is for World Wide Web, representing Tim Berners-Leersquos invention of the internet, and G is for Greenwich Mean Time, celebrating Britainrsquos naval history and establishing a global timescale.Quintessentially British food and drink such as cups of tea, fish and chips, English breakfasts and ice-cream cones also appear, along with defining national traits such as queuing.Q is for QueuingThe natural world is represented in R for robins, the red-breasted garden bird which makes the UK its home the whole year round, and oak trees taking up the letter Os slot.The Houses or Parliament represent H, while the myth of King Arthurs has been picked for the letter K. Other things judged to be "Quintessentially British" enough to make the list include the National Health Service , Stonehengeand villagesand the Queens jubilee .The p collection comes after a set of  pence coins celebrating the th anniversary of the literary monster The Gruffalo, created while its author Julia Donaldson lived in Glasgow, have been released.The Royal Mint launched the commemorative coins depicting the distinctive beast with orange eyes, poisonous wart and purple prickle earlier this month for collectors, not general circulation.The beloved childrens story was first published  years ago accompanied by colourful illustrations from Axel Scheffler. It went on to sell . million copies worldwide.:Royal Mint designed p coin to mark Queens Diamond JubileeMs Donaldson said: "I cant believe it has been  years since The Gruffalo was first published."In that time, hes been brought to le on stage and screen, featured in nature trails, library cards and book tokens and turned into a soft toy and now hes got his own p coin."

title: public-health-experts-call-for-ban-on-army-recruiting-under-18s
story: More than one in fivepeople joining the UK army are children aged  to , but experts are calling for the age threshold to be raised.Read more: Army on standby in preparation for no-deal BrexitThe UK is the only European country and permanent member of the UN Security Council to recruit -year-olds.Children as young as  can begin the enlistment process, with two years of training starting from the age of  prior to first deployment at .Writing today in the journal, BMJ Open Paediatrics, the researchers from charity Medact say that current recruitment practices "capitalise on a window of vulnerability" during adolescence, and disproportionately target youngsters from the lowest socioeconomic groups.Read more: Avoidable deaths among children and teens in Scotland highest in UKReem Abu-Hayyeh, of Medact, and Dr Guddi Singh, an integrated child health specialist, said military service at this age exposes them to the risk of long lasting and complex effects on mental and physical health.They said evidence shows younger recruits more vulnerable to self-harm, suicide, and alcohol misuse, associated with the isolation and culture of military le as well as the trauma of active combat.Read more: Childrens commissioner says youths from deprived backgrounds should not be targeted by Army recruitmentThe British Army says it is facing a personnel shortfall of  but the researchers insist the recruitment policy is "misguided and counterproductive", pointing to figures showing that those recruited under  account for % of those who leave the Armed Forces voluntarily before completing their service.Concerns have previously been raised in Scotland about the Ministry of Defence targeting recruitment drives to schools in deprived communities.

title: holyrood-to-vote-on-opt-out-organ-donations
story: Holyrood will decide on whether to back the principles of a law which would presume consent for donations from the dead, unless people had stipulated otherwise.The Human TissueScotland Bill is intended to increase the supply of organs for donation and help more patients in need.Ministers say the replacement for the current opt-in system would include safeguards to ensure donation does not go aheadit would be clearly against the personrsquos wishes.Less than  per cent of people die in circumstances that enable organ donation to proceed, with potential donors having usually been in an intensive care unit.Even then, there may be medical reasons making organs unsuitable for transplantation.SNP Public Health Minister Joe FitzPatrick said: ldquoOrgan and tissue donation can be a le-changing gt, and has the power to both save and improve lives.ldquoIn Scotland we have seen tremendous progress over the last decade, with the number of donors, organ and tissue transplants all increasing."There has also been a signicant increase in the number of people registering their donation decision, with % of the Scottish population on the NHS Organ Donor Register - the highest rate of all UK countries.ldquoHowever, there are still too many people waiting for transplants, with an average of more than  people waiting for an organ transplant at any one point in Scotland.

title: tv-review-move-over-piers-morgan-alan-partridge-is-back-a-ha
story: ON being asked by an interviewerhe was ever tempted to stray during his marriage, Paul Newman famously inquired why he should go out for hamburger when he had steak at home.In the same vein, is there a place for a new Alan Partridge series in a world where Richard Madeley and Piers Morgan exist The answer came with the first giggle raised by This Time with Alan Partridge, and for half an hour the yucks kept coming, like zombie apes queuing up to play monkey tennis. If we must have one borderline bonkers television presenter with an ego visible from space then it has to be the original and best. Sorry, Piers. Suck it up, Ricardo.Marianne Taylor: BBC better off without NeilWhen we meet Alan again he is filling in for a poorly colleague on a programme not a million miles from The One Show. His co-presenter, Jennie , steals his jokes and rolls her eyes at every opportunity, and there were lots. ldquoIrsquom a married woman, said Jennie as he flirted with her, live on air. ldquoI was told you were separated, was Alanrsquos attempt at a witty rejoinder.There were some sharp jabs at the fly-by-the-seat-of-your-pants live television, with a mistake corrected by a tweet which was subsequently amended by an email. Mostly, though, the focus was Alan. His twitching. His chinos. His tie pin. The man is an emotional grenade.Book review: Limmy at his bestSome things did not work. The set was too big, though this did lend itself to a Spinal Tap-style walk by Alan in the worldrsquos noisiest shoes. But for the most part, Coogan, plus fellow writers Neil and Rob Gibbons, were on top form. Sidekick Simon was back with a ldquodigiwall that he could not operate Alan was heckled in traditional fashion while out filminghis assistant Lynn hates Jennie. It is going to end in tears, but of the good kind.ldquoDo you think Paul McCartney is watching this  Alan, needy as a newborn, asked Lynn. If he isnrsquot, hersquos a mug.

title: oscars-review-no-hosts-means-less-in-jokes-more-music-intrigue-and-politics
story: All that happened was we had a few less egos and baffling in-joke monologues leaving viewers to concentrate on what the Academy Awards are all about, star watching.The headline acts of the  Oscars were an array of the great and the good of the movie industry desperate to get their hands on a gold statuette, rather than a comedian whose humour often did not translate to a worldwide audience. Jimmy Kimmel may be a big name in the US but means little where yet was the host in .That might have been a reason why the ceremonys live audience last year was the lowest in in Oscars history, averaging . million viewers, down from . million in .What we ended up with was a st Academy Awards ceremony that felt less bloated but actually ran for about the same three-houras its predecessors.In the absence of a monologue, the ceremony kicked off with original Queen members Brian May and Roger Taylor rolling back the years, joined by Adam Lambert for a mini-medley of the bands classic songs featuring We Are The Champions and We Will Rock You, bringing the star-studded Oscars audience to its feet.It was the music rather than the laughs that stole the show.The immaculately choreographed performance of the Oscar winning original song Shallow by actor director Bradley Cooper and singer actress Lady Gaga was perhaps the most memorable moment of the night.With cameras placed at the back of the stage, the curtain lted and crew pusha grand piano into place with an array of blinding headlamps kissing the empty stage leaving viewers wondering what on earth was going on.Then the duo stephand-in-hand from their seats in the audience, Cooper helping Lady Gaga, whose shimmering, sleek Celine dress was a potential hazard, up the stairs to the stage.With the TV audiencestill with a back-of-stage view, Cooper sings, and Gaga stands staring into his eyes before taking her position behind the piano to play her part in this most intimate of love songs.Cooper then joins her on her piano stool and they become cocooned, steamily cheek to cheek for the denouement. It all feels so spine-tinglingly real, you do wonder what was going through the mind of Coopers partner, Russian supermodel Irina Shayk.They exitto a standing ovation, but it was, of course, meat and drink for the gossipmongers. Even Spice Girl Mel B who was a guest on the special broadcast said she was left feeling ldquouncomfortable for Coopers girlfriend.It was of course, supposed to be an act, an exercise of romantic artice, and a spin on their starring roles in the Star Is Born remake. If you like, it was four minutes encapsulating what moviemaking is about - making you believe.The laughs were less scripted.British actress Olivia Colman has come a long way from the days of her understated role as a scruffy and unstable love interest of the socially awkward and despondent loan manager played by David Mitchell in Peep Show.Since then she has become a serial winner of awards for her acting culminating in her first, surely of many, best actress Oscar for her role as as Queen Anne, the erratic and gout-ridden monarch in The Favourite.Her endearingly scatterbrained and scattergun speech has to go down as one of the most bizarre, emotional yet hilarious acceptances in recent years.She began by wiping the tears from eyes and said: "Ooooh, its genuinely quite stressful... this is hilarious. Got an Oscar."In a typicallyoff-the-cuff acceptance speech, Colman said she wanted to ldquothanks lots of people and thatshe forgot anyone she would find them later and give them ldquoa massive snog.Colman said how shocked she was to be there, having once worked as a cleaner and then blew a raspberry as she was asked to wind up.She also thanked Glenn Close, who was widely tipped as the likely best actress winner, saying she had been ldquoher idol for so long this is not how I wanted it to be.She went on to thank her children Finn,  and Hall, , adding she ldquohopes they are at home and watching, because ldquothis isnrsquot going to happen again.The Oscars have major flaws, of course, and viewers have to swallow the conceit that the best movies appear to be American.And, of course, the winning films are often worthy and issue-driven with action blockbusters, comedy and horror barely getting a look in.. So the best picture winner was race relations drama Green Book and included among the eight nominated best picture gongs are BlacKkKlansman, a movie about an African-American detective inflitrating the Ku Klux Klan, and Roma, a Mexican drama about the Mexican director Alfonso Cuaroacuten upbringing in the Colonia Roma neighborhood of Mexico City.Its asthe Academy are making a conscious effort to love Mexico in the midst of Donald Trumps determination to pledge to build a border wall.If that was not obvious politicisation over art, then Spike Lees comments while accepting the Best Adapted Screenplay award for BlacKkKlansman definitely was.He implored Americans to praise ancestors "stolen from Mother Africa" who have "built this country into what it is today along with the genocide of its native people".He said during Sunday nightrsquos ceremony: ldquoThe  presidential election is around the corner. Letrsquos all mobilise. Letrsquos all be on the right side of history. Make the moral choice between love versus hate. Letrsquos do the right thing.Trump, who is on his way to a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in Vietnam, responded with a personal jab on Twitter saying: ldquoBe niceSpike Lee could read his notes, or better yet not have to use notes at all, when doing his racist hit on your president, who has done more for African Americansthan almost any other pres!The controversy over Lee did not end there. He would later declare ldquothe ref made a bad call when Green Book won and reportedly tried to storm out of the Dolby Theatre after the announcement.Green Book, based on a true story of the friendship between a black pianist and his white driver touring the racially segregated deep south during the s, also won for best original screenplay and supporting actor, Mahershala Ali.In the press room backstage, Lee recalled that his film Do the Right Thing had failed to earn a best picture nomination for the Oscars in , the year that Driving Miss Daisy ndash about a black chauffeur for a white elderly southern woman ndash won the award.ldquoIrsquom snakebit. Every time someone is driving somebody, I lose, Lee said.The director, a fan of the New York Knicks basketball team, said when he heard Green Book announced as the yearrsquos best picture winner: ldquoI thought I was courtside at the [Madison Square] Garden, and the ref made a bad call.

title: david-pratt-outsiders-are-playing-fast-and-loose-with-the-fate-of-venezuela
story: A military escalation is the last thing the country needs, but such are the high stakes for both sides in this struggle for power there seems an increasing readiness to go down that route.The ldquoall options are on the table talk that some weeks ago characterised the rhetoric coming out of Washington in support of the Venezuelan opposition and echoed in response by the government of President Nicolas Maduro, now has a distinctly scary ring.Yesterday Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido only added to that fear as he met US Vice President Mike Pence and asked other countries to consider ldquoall options to remove President Maduro from power.Mr Guidorsquos request in all likelihood will only further intensy a violent situation on the ground that last weekend saw clashes between opposition forces and security forces as well as armed supporters loyal to Mr Maduro that led to several deaths and hundreds being injured.The most dramatic scenes unfolded on Saturday on the bridges connecting the Colombian city of Cucuta to Venezuelan towns across the Tachira River.There, Mr Guaido, now recognised by dozens of countries as Venezuelarsquos legitimate interim president, called for convoys of humanitarian aid to be let into his beleaguered nation.For weeks Mr Guaido trumpeted the day as the moment when Venezuelarsquos long-suffering people would get the aid they so desperately needed. But some say what might have been a masterplan to increase pressure on Mr Maduro has only pushed the country down an even more chaotic course towards civil war.It was a gesture say critics of Mr Guaido that had more to do with provocation than humanitarianism and which left some global organisations like the UN and the International Committee of the Red Crosswarning all sides of the dangers in ldquoweaponising aid. Perhaps the most worrying aspect in all of this however is the apparent willingness of other outside players to play fast and loose with the fate of Venezuela and its people.Just what did US Senator Mark Rubio think would be the outcome of him posting two photographs of former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi on his Twitter account on Sunday Itrsquos well known of course that Mr Rubio is an influential voice in Washington on Venezuela policy and a staunch critic of Mr Maduro. But his tweet showing the Libyan leader bloodied and injured shortly before his death at the hands of rebel militiamen is the crudest and most incendiary of messages to Mr Maduro.That Mr Rubio had previously tweeted another photo of former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, who was captured in  after a US military invasion, is likewise unequivocal it its meaning and can, as intended, only be read one way by Mr Maduro. The message is simple, your time is up and forcenecessary, will be used.How Mr Rubio and those in Washington think such gestures strengthen their case for democratic change in Venezuela is baffling. Surely rather that stoke an already dangerously volatile situation, the US government should be doing all it can to ensure that such a process happens through the ballot box The Trump administration is now clearly losing patience with Mr Maduro and no longer cares how he is removed from office so long as he is and their chosen leader Mr Guaido takes over.Just last week President Trump at a speech in Miami urged ldquoVenezuelan patriots to rise up against the regime. Mr Guaido at the weekend did the same on Twitter.ldquoTodayrsquos events force me to make a decision to formally propose to the international community that we must have all options open to secure the freedom our country.For many Latin America analysts such talk bodes ill and presents serious warning signs.ldquoThere is no question that a military intervention to resolve the Venezuela crisis is more plausible than ever, Michael Shter, president of the Inter-American Dialogue, a US-based think- tank, told the Washington Post over the last few days as the crisis deepened.ldquoGuaidorsquos insistence that lsquoall options are on the tablersquo echoes President Trumprsquos words, first uttered in August  and widely interpreted as serious consideration of military action, warned Mr Shter.Some observers however insist that the US history of attempted regime change in the Latin American region and Mr Trumprsquos loose language are both working against the opposition that faces a still formidable foe in Mr Madurorsquos regime.Many Venezuelans remain suspicious of Washingtonrsquos motives, evenyet more defections to the opposition from within the ranks of the Venezuelan security forces have taken place over the past few days.More than  members of Venezuelarsquos armed forces defected during the clashes last weekend, with Mr Guaido promising the defectors would be given amnesty and congratulating them on joining ldquothe right side of history.Mr Maduro meanwhile still believes himself to be on the right side of history evenlast weekendrsquos blockade of foreign aid has left him facing a diplomatic siege.As the crisis worsens UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has appealed for ldquoviolence to be avoided at any cost and insisted everyone should lower tensions.Washington however is paying little heed and more than ever seems intent in doing whatever it takes to get its way in Venezuela. ldquoThe eyes of the entire world are upon you today, every day, and every day in the future, Mr Trump told Mr Madruo in a speech last week. ldquoYou cannot hide from the choice that now confronts you, the US president warned.For now all eyes are on the outcome of yesterdayrsquos meeting in the Colombian capital Bogota between Mr Pence and Mr GuaidoIf indeed all options are on the table, as both men have made clear, then Venezuela might be about to face the most dangerous moment in this crisis so far. What an even greater catastrophe it would beUS military intervention were the option chosen.

title: scotland-could-lose-730m-in-post-brexit-funding-without-replacement-cash-says-analysis
story: Scotland could lose £m in post-Brexit funding without UK replacement cash, says analysisSNP seeks cross-party support to ensure Whitehall gives #like-for-like replaltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtcement# for EU fltspan classtruncate-full-screengtundsThe SNP is seeking cross-party support to pressure the UK Government into preventing the estimated loss in financial aid of more than poundm.The calculation has come from the Conference of Peripheral Maritime Regions, a think-tank and lobbying organisation, which brings together some  regions from##EU states to campaign for a more balanced development across the continent.Its analysis concludes Brexit would be ldquodisastrous for development, estimating that between  and  Scotland could lose funding worth some poundm ie more than poundm a year.The Nationalist leadership has written to David Mundell, the Scottish Secretary, Lesley Laird, his Labour Shadow, and Christine Jardine of the Liberal Democrats, urging them all to work together to pressure the Conservative Government to ensure that, following the planned transition period, it delivers a ldquolike-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.The SNP has pointed out that while the UK Government has committed to continue aid funding until , there has been no clarity on the so-called Shared Prosperity Fund, the proposed replacement for the EU development funds after this date.Last week, Scottish and Welsh Finance Ministers met with UK Government ministers seeking clarity on future funding arrangements but they insisted none was forthcoming.Drew Hendry, the SNPrsquos Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy spokesman, said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK Government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead, then the UK Government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose.Mr Hendry, who represents Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey, said it was shocking that the Government had already broken its own word by failing to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and insisted it could not ldquoweasel out of its responsibilities.ldquoIt is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland," he added.A spokesman for the UK Government said it recognised the importance of reassuring communities on the future of local growth funding once Britain left the EU.ldquoWe have guaranteed existing EU funding commitments until the end of  and are making good progress on the design of the UK Shared Prosperity Fund. We will, of course, work in partnership with the devolved administrations to ensure this works for the whole of the UK.The consultation on the Governmentrsquos replacement fund will be published ldquoin due course.

title: brexit-jeremy-corbyn-moves-to-back-second-eu-poll-with-remain-on-ballot-paper
story: The dramatic move came as Theresa Mayrsquos plane touched down following her trip to Egypt when she insisted a deal with Brussels was ldquowithin our grasp.But she placed herself on a collision course with a large number of Tory colleagues, including some in the Cabinet, when she set her face against calls to put back exit day from March  to allow more time for talks.Today, she will update MPs on the ldquoprogress in the Brussels talks key will be the wording of the Government motion to be debated and voted on tomorrow evening.After days of senior figures saying Labour was ldquomoving towards supporting a Peoplersquos Vote, Mr Corbyn announced the sht during a two-hour meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party at Westminster.He explained Labour would table its own amendment, calling for a customs union with a UK say and close alignment with the single market, and would also support his colleague Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment to extend the Article  process to avoid a no-deal outcome.But, signicantly, the party leader said,those failed, Labour would back an amendment ldquoin favour of a public vote to prevent a damaging Tory Brexit".A senior party source said the ldquoassumption would be that Remain would be on the ballot paper but made clear it would not be a straight choice between the Governmentrsquos deal and Remain as the former was unacceptable ious options were being considered.But not everyone was happy. Backbencher John Mann reportedly claimed people in the North of England would "never vote Labour again". He told Mr Corbyn: ldquoThis decision will stop you being Prime Minister.

title: brexit-stakes-raised-jeremy-corbyn-backs-peoples-vote-and-theresa-may-refuses-to-delay-exit-day
story: As the febrile atmosphere at Westminster intensied ahead of tomorrowrsquos Commons vote, the Prime Minister ed to Britain from her attendance at the EU-Arab summit in Sharm el-Sheikh as the Labour leader was addressing a packed private meeting of the parliamentary party in the Commons.During the two-hour conclave, passionate contributions could be heard from outside the Gladstone Room as journalists waited in the committee corridor.Mr Corbyn told MPs: "The Prime Minister is recklessly running down the clock in an attempt to force MPs to choose between her botched deal and a disastrous no-deal. We cannot and will not accept that.He said Labours alternative Brexit plan - contained in an amendment - for a comprehensive customs union with a UK say, close alignment with the single market and guarantees on rights and standards was ldquoserious and credible.The party leader made clear Labour would also be backing the amendment, proposed by his colleague Yvette Cooper, to extend the Article  process in a bid to rule out a no-deal outcome.ldquoOne way or another, we will do everything in our power to prevent no-deal and oppose a damaging Tory Brexit based on Theresa Mays overwhelmingly rejected deal, declared Mr Corbyn.Then he added: "Thats why, in line with our conference policy, we are committed to also putting forward or supporting an amendment in favour of a public vote to prevent a damaging Tory Brexit being forced on the country."At first there was a deal of confusion as to whether an option to Remain would be on the ballot paper of a Labour-supported Peoplersquos Vote. Some Remainer MPs emerged unsure as they said Mr Corbyn had not been specic about the Remain option in his answers.But others insisted the position was clear. One peer said Remain would ldquoinevitably be on the ballot paper, stressing: ldquoOtherwise what would be the point  You canrsquot have a Peoplersquos Vote with one question.Backbencher Owen Smith, who challenged for the leadership in , said: ldquoThis was always the right policy for Labour. This is where we should have been at the beginning.His Labour colleague Ian Murray, a leading Remainer, described the leadershiprsquos position as ldquounequivocal, adding: ldquoThis is signicant progress and now we must win the arguments to get a majority in Parliament to win a public vote with the option to remain.But some MPs were unhappy. Lucy Powell, who represents Manchester Central, estimated some  colleagues would vote against a second referendum.John Mann, the Nottinghamshire MP, claimed people in the North of England would "never vote Labour again". He told Mr Corbyn: ldquoThis decision will stop you being Prime Minister.Meanwhile, Brandon Lewis, the Conservative Chairman, accused the Labour leadership of having ldquoripped up their promise to respect the referendum result.He added: ldquoJeremy Corbyns Labour want to betray the will of the British people and ignore the biggest democratic vote in our nations history.It is thought part of the Labour leadershiprsquos calculation was to try to stem the defections to the centrist pro-Remain Independent Group, which has seen eight MPs leave Labour to join it.Today, the Government is expected to table the motion for debate tomorrow. While some MPs have suggested Mrs May might try to kill off support for the Cooper amendment by signalling she would not allow the country to crash out of the EU without a deal, she was adamant in Sharm el-Sheikh that she would not support extending Article .The PM told a press conference: ldquoA delay in this process does not deliver a decision in Parliament, it doesnrsquot deliver a deal what it does is precisely what the word says.After a raft of meetings on the sidelines, which included talks with Germanyrsquos Angela Merkel, Irelandrsquos Leo Varadkar and the European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, Mrs May told journalists: ldquoI have a real sense from the meetings I have had here, conversations I have had with EU leaders in recent dayshellipwe can achieve that deal. Itrsquos within our grasp to leave with a deal on March  and thatrsquos where all our energies are going to be focused.The PM, who has put off having a meaningful vote this week but promised one by March , admitted there was ldquostill more work to do.But she noted: ldquoWhat I have sensed in all of my conversations with my fellow leaders both here in Sharm el-Sheikh and in recent days is a real determination to find a way through, which allows the UK to leave the EU in a smooth and orderly way with a deal.

title: neil-mackay-it-is-time-to-bring-football-to-heel-as-roughly-as-possible
story: There would have been outrage among parentsthe schools I attended ndash ordinary, religiously mixed, state-owned ndash had been seen to passively collude with such behaviour by not coming down like a tonne of bricks on the offending pupil.Failure to deal with such offensive behaviour in the most punitive way possible would have been a green light for pupils to behave like animals. A culture of ugly bullying, of neanderthal bigotry, would have been allowed to fester inside schools doing their best to instil respect and decency in children growing up within a hate-filled sectarian society scarred by The Troubles.That zero tolerance approach to bigotry within the school gates probably helped create a generation which turned its back on religious hatred and ushered in an end to violence and the beginnings of peace in the s. To be uncompromisingly tough with the worst excesses of human behaviour is often the only way to help forge a better world.So itrsquos little wonder that Scottish football, the Old Firm, and their toxic tribes of hardcore bigoted fans disgust me. Sadly, outside of Scotland, football in this country is seen through the prism of Rangers and Celtic. The Old Firm is Scottish football to most of the world. Fans of other teams may not like that fact, but itrsquos the case ndash what the Old Firm does reflects on the entire Scottish game, on every team and fan.When bitter anti-Catholic Rangers fans call Steve Clarke, the Kilmarnock manager, a ldquoFenian b******, when bitter anti-Protestant Celtic fans call Kris Boyd, the Kilmarnock striker, an ldquoOrange b******, everyone outside Scotland sees the game and its supporters through this lens.I cannot believe that supporters who view themselves as decent human beings would wish to be in any way associated with the glamorisation of sectarian hatred, with the glorication of terrorism ndash as revealed in the vile and petty songs and banners of the worst fans in both clubs. How can you support a team, or go to a game, where religious hatred exists in any form  In any other walk of le ndash any other business ndash such behaviour would spell a mass exodus of public support and concomitant financial collapse. But football is given a place of exceptionalism - and so for some, social norms can be disregarded and society debased while money is made.Decent supporters of Rangers and Celtic ndash of whom there are many ndash may not like to be lumped in with the UVF-adulating mob at Ibrox, or the IRA-supporting mob at Celtic Park, but to many people yoursquore judged by the company you keep. If I stand peaceably in a crowd enjoying a game of football but within that same crowd there are fans chanting ldquoFenian b****** or ldquoOrange b******rsquorsquo, I have to accept that this isnrsquot a good look for me. Some might see me as guilty by association. Some might see me as passively accepting what is happening. Some might see me as too cowardly to disassociate myself from such behaviour. Some might think I get a little vicarious thrill from what is going on. At the very best Irsquom guilty of being a bystander ndash of deciding the game, the club, is more important than common decency.But supporters are supporters, and clubs are quite a dferent thing, and some ndash like Rangers and Celtic, it could be saidndash sit atop mountains of gold mined from bigotry and hatred. Perhaps these clubs havenrsquot deliberately enriched themselves by allowing sectarianism to flourish within their grounds, but as long as such behaviour continues they are guilty of passive acceptance, of a failure of responsibility.If I own a company and a byproduct of my work as a business is something seen as a social ill, then I have to take responsibility for it. Social media companies are being pilloried every day ndash rightly ndash for failing to act over fake news or abuse. The CEOs are dragged before politicians, therersquos public talk of boycotts. But with football, itrsquos simply a matter of exceptionalism.Irsquom sick to death of hearing excuses for the so-called beautul game ndash itrsquos a bloody ugly game and it needs dragged to heel as roughly as possible. Humza Yousaf spoke for a silent majority of decent people across Scotland at the weekend when he issued what he called ldquoa very stark warning to football clubs. Mr Yousaf said that the ldquoGovernment is looking at every single option that is on the table, including strict liability and stadium licensing. I cheered as loudly as any football fan when I heard him say that. Mr Yousaf has put the clubs on warning thatthey donrsquot act, the Government will.ldquoStrict liability is just a complicated way of saying the clubs will be fined and suffer other sanctions, and stadium licensing means that a game could be played with no fans in attendance. Mr Yousaf should impose a ticking clock now, giving the clubs a limited window of time to get their act together. If, and when, the clubs fail to take what he described as ldquodefinitive measures to deal with sectarianism then the Government needs to take control and pass legislation ndash and make the legislation draconian, so once a club is hit, the fines and empty stadiums will leave them cowed and obedient.Similarly, the police and prosecution service must ensure that any breach of the law by fans within or outwith football grounds is cracked down on fearsomely. If a fan so much as drops litter in the street, then arrest them. Anything even remotely resembling harassment or intimidation should end in court and a criminal record.Docking of points should be a regular sanction ndash either legislation should cover it, or government should strong-arm footballing authorities to use such powers. Hit the clubs where it hurts: in their pockets, and wreck ambitions for sporting glory.When football in Scotland becomes a sport that you would happily take your children to, then and only then can it call itself the beautul game.Read more: Whataboutery is no defence

title: chinas-social-credit-system-a-ratings-nightmare-straight-out-of-black-mirror-or-an-exercise-in-rebuilding-trust
story: ldquoOnce you lose trust,the slogan says, ldquoyou will face restrictions everywhere.By , every citizen will have a centrally-logged lsquosocial creditrsquo score, akin to a credit reference. But it does not just measure their financial standing.So far introduced on a voluntary basispoints are lost for misdemeanours ndash such as failing to pay a fine. But other anti-social behaviour will also be penalised: smoking in the wrong place, posting the the wrong thing on social media, jaywalking or even buying too many video games.Those whose score drops too far could be banned from certain jobs, or enrolling in college. Good scores may make it easier to get loans or visas for foreign travel. But the Government has already banned millions of people with low social credit ratings from air and train travel.
