title: brexit-latest-theresa-may-offers-mps-article-50-delay-vote
story: Mrs May confirmed that she will put her Withdrawal Agreement, including whatever additional assurances she has secured from Brussels, to a "meaningful vote" by March .If that fails, MPs will be offered two separate votes on the following days - one on a no-deal Brexit and,that is defeated, the other on requesting an extension to the two-year Article  negotiation process to delay EU withdrawal beyond March .Read more: Brexit fallout liveThe sequence of votes will be proposed in an amendable motion tabled by the Prime Minister for debate and vote in the Commons on Wednesday.To uproar in the Commons, Mrs May told MPs: "They are commitments I am making as Prime Minister and I will stick by them, as I have previous commitments to make statements and table amendable motions by specic dates."But she added: "Let me be clear, I do not want to see Article  extended. Our absolute focus should be on working to get a deal and leaving on March ."Read more:Jeremy Corbyn moves to back second EU poll - with Remain on ballot paperIn a statement to MPs following a Cabinet meeting with senior colleagues at  Downing Street, Theresa May said she wanted to set out "three further commitments" to the Commons.She said: "First, we will hold a second meaningful vote by Tuesday March  at the latest."Second,the Government has not won a meaningful vote by Tuesday March , then it will - in addition to its obligations to table a neutral amendable motion under Section  of the EU Withdrawal Act - table a motion to be voted on by Wednesday March  at the latest, asking this Houseit supports leaving the EU without a Withdrawal Agreement and a framework for a future relationship on March ."So the United Kingdom will only leave without a deal on March there is explicit consent in the House for that outcome."Third,the House, having rejected the deal negotiated with the EU, then rejects leaving on March  without a Withdrawal Agreement and future framework, the Government will on March  bring forward a motion on whether Parliament wants to seek a short, limited extension to Article ."If MPs vote for an extension, the Government will "seek to agree that extension approved by the House with the EU, and bring forward the necessary legislation to change the exit date commensurate with that extension", said Mrs May.The Prime Minister said that an extension of Article  beyond the end of June would require the UK to take part in European Parliament elections in May and that a shorter extension would "almost certainly have to be a one-off"."An extension cannot take no-deal off the table," she warned. "The only way to do that is to revoke Article , which I shall not do, or agree a deal."Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said that Mrs May appeared to be adopting the terms of a cross-party amendment put forward by Yvette Cooper and Sir Oliver Letwin designed to prevent no-dealher Withdrawal Agreement is voted down on March .But he told MPs: "Until the Prime Minister is clear what alternative she would put forward in that circumstance, then she is continuing to run down the clock."She promises a short extension but for what "Mr Corbyn confirmed that Labour will table an amendment to the Governments motion calling for a deal based on its priorities of a customs union, close alignment with the single market and matching EU workplace and environmental rights."If the Government wants a genuine renegotiation it should do so on terms that can win a majority of this House, on terms backed by businesses and unions and that are contained within Labours amendment, which I urge the whole House to back tomorrow," he said.The Prime Minister hit out at Mr Corbyn over Labours support for a second referendum."He has gone back on his promise to respect the referendum result and now wants to hold a isive second referendum that would take our country right back to square one," she said."Anyone who voted Labour at the last election because they thought he would deliver Brexit will rightly be appalled."

title: nicola-sturgeon-announces-funding-for-women-leaders-scheme
story: :Brexit latest: Theresa May offers MPs Article  delay voteThe scheme matches up women entrepreneurs with established female business mentors, assisting women as they moving into leadership roles.Part of the initiative aims to stimulate the "internationalisation" of Scottish business, the Scottish Government said.Speaking at the Edinburgh Chamber of Commerce Women in Business lunch, the First Minister said the scheme will "help some of the next generation of women business leaders as they start their careers".She said: "Helping more women to set up and succeed in business is both an economic and a moral imperative."By encouraging and supporting women to create and grow businesses, we can create greater equality which in turn builds a stronger and fairer economy."The Scottish Chambers of Commerce has a pool of more than , mentors across Scotland.:Class ide as richest pupils still dominate university placesThe organisations chief executive, Liz Cameron, said: "It is an economic priority to ensure that we create an infrastructure which will unlock the outstanding opportunities which exist for females in the workplace enabling more of us to progress to the very top."It will also be a beacon for others to follow, and at the same time, increase the number of successful businesses run by women to grow and expand their businesses."Mentoring will be integral to our focus, but it will be in wider terms of bringing together business leaders and other organisations who want to play a role in this development."We are also excited at bringing in an international dimension, identying potentially new connections and new orders."

title: richard-leonard-defies-majority-of-scots-to-back-brexit-over-second-referendum
story: The Scottish Labour leader saidit came to a vote, he would support Remain.THE SNP said the remark would "utterly dismay" many Labour supporters.Mr Leonard also suggested thatBrexit was delayed, it ought to be for longer than the two months posited by Number , eventhat meant fighting the next European elections.The ardent Corbyn-supporter was speaking after Labour MSPs discussed the latest developments on Brexit at their weekly meeting at Holyrood today.He said thatLabour could not amend Theresa Mayrsquos deal as it wished, the party would back a second vote offering a choice between Remain and a ldquocredible Leave option.He said Leave options might include no-deal, Mrs Mayrsquos deal or a iant of her deal.He said Labour wanted a Brexit with a permanent customs union, close alignment with the single market, access to EU agencies and funding, security cooperation, and guarantees on workers rights, consumer protection and the environment.Asked whether his preference was for that deal or a referendum, he said: ldquoFor that deal.Scots voted - against Brexit in , and polls show similar numbers of Scots continue to oppose it.Asked why he was setting himself against the majority of Scottish voters, Mr Leonard said: ldquoWell, because the referendum on the EU in the end was a UK-wide franchise, and that was the outcome of the people who took part.:Most Scottish Labour MPs now back new Brexit voteMr Leonard, who became leader in November , acknowledged Nationalists would use a second EU referendum to call for a second independence referendum.However, downplaying the signicance of that, he said those agitating for independence would always seize on the flimsiest pretext to do so.Mr Leonard suggested thatMPs backed an extension to Brexit next month, it ought to be longer than the two months to the end of June identied by Mrs May.He said: ldquoI donrsquot think simply putting a time limit of two months on it is right.ldquoI think that the extension needs to take account of the fact that there is work to be done on trying to find a deal thatrsquos acceptable.ldquoI think that there is growing evidence from the European Commission that they are prepared to lend credibility to the Labour option which is going to be put before parliament this week.ldquoI think given there are signals from the EU negotiating team that they would be prepared to work with that deal, I think itrsquos important the UK parliament gives proper consideration to that and I sincerely hope that the UK parliament would vote for that.Askedhe was therefore happy with an extension that took the UK into the next European Parliament session, he said: ldquoI actually think that this decision is more important than the electoral cycle of the European parliament.:Richard Leonard on Brexit: Now is the time to act and act radicallyHe said Labourrsquos Scottish Executive Committee had already discussed what it would do in the event of it having to contest the European poll in May, but refused to reveal them.Labour won two of the six MEP positions in Scotland at the last election in .However one of those MEPs, Catherine Stihler, has already stood down to take up another job, meaning the party might need to find another candidate rapidly.Asked about Nicola Sturgeon ldquomaking hay with Mr Leonard backing Brexit, Scottish Labour Brexit spokesman Neil Findlay said: ldquoNicola Sturgeon has had about seven dferent positions on Brexit. She has regularly called for there to be a customs union.ldquoI think she would support Labourrsquos position in terms of the rights of people, whether they be workers or protecting the environment or all the rest of it. I donrsquot think therersquos a great deal in the Labour proposals that...they would object to.:Blow for Richard Leonard as leak reveals , Labour membership slump across ScotlandSNP MSP George Adam said:ldquoRichard Leonard has today confirmed that Scottish Labour is pro-Brexit ndash something that will utterly dismay many of its own supporters.ldquoThe clock is ticking on Brexit and we desperately need parties to work together against Theresa Mayrsquos bad deal and against no-deal. ldquoBut almost as soon as Labour say they could support a second referendum, Richard Leonard says it would be better for Brexit to go ahead.ldquoThat puts Labour completely at odds with the Scottish people ndash and it makes their apparent embrace of a second referendum look cynical in the extreme.ldquoItrsquos time for all parties to throw their weight behind a public vote, with Remain on the ballot, and put an end to this Brexit mess.

title: brexit-jeremy-corbyn-faces-backlash-over-second-referendum-plan
story: Mr Corbyn saidTheresa Mays Brexit deal gets through Parliament "there must be a confirmatory public vote".:Theresa May offers MPs Article  delay voteThe sht in policy, which would see voters asked to decide between a deal and remaining in the EU, won plaudits from Remain-supporting MPs but led to warnings of electoral disaster in some of Labours heartlands.The move also led to a spat between shadow cabinet ministers and anonymous party sources over the details of the pledge.Speaking in the Commons, Mr Corbyn said: "The Prime Ministers botched deal provides no certainty or guarantees for the future and was comprehensively rejected by this House."We cannot risk our countrys industry and peoples livelihoods and soit somehow does pass in some form at a later stage, we believe there must be a confirmatory public vote to seepeople feel it is what they voted for."Labour has said it will either support a motion calling for a referendum or table one itself.Labour MP John Mann said the move would be "catastrophic to Labour in the Midlands and the north".:Richard Leonard defies majority of Scots to back Brexit over second referendumThe Bassetlaw MP, who voted to leave the EU, told BBC Radio s Today: "Voters wont have it. The last person to renege on their manesto was Nick Clegg, it didnt end very well for him on tuition fees."Our manesto was unambiguous, we would accept the result of the referendum. A second referendum doesnt do that and the voters - in very, very large numbers - will not accept that."Stoke Central MP Gareth Snell suggested that shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer had engineered the sht in Labours stance."If I was being a bit unkind, part of me thinks this has been what Keir wanted all along, to move the Labour Party to a point of so much confusion this seems to be the only way forward," he told the BBC."Which is disappointing, because in the early days I thought he really wants to speak to those of us in leave areas who have real concerns, not just for what this means for our party but what this means for the connection our party has with those communities.":Brexit: Jeremy Corbyn moves to back second EU poll - with Remain on ballot paperMeanwhile, senior shadow Cabinet ministers defended the policy amid suggestions senior party sources were briefing against them.Sir Keir told BBC Radio s Today that "elected politicians" - rather than aides - were setting out the Labour position.Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry said: "Ive seen some nonsense that I misspoke earlier on a public vote."Pretty hard to misspeak identically in  interviews, but for clarity:Theresa May wont accept our deal, then the public must decide: do we accept whatever deal she gets through, or do we Remain  Got it "Deputy Labour leader Tom Watson said: "Whoever briefed that my colleague misspoke undermines the sovereignty of the current shadow cabinet."The Prime Minister claimed the policy sht meant Mr Corbyn "has gone back on his promise to respect the referendum result and now wants to hold a isive second referendum that would take our country right back to square one"."Anyone who voted Labour at the last election because they thought he would deliver Brexit will rightly be appalled," she said.

story: A. title: embroidery exhibition at heritage centre
story: The Garioch Heritage Centre in Inverurie will host the Embroiderer#s Guild Lest We Forget embroidery exhibition next week.The free exhibition will run at the centre from Tuesday, February  to Tuesday, March .In  the Guild in conjunction with SSAFAinvited its members to take part in the commemoration of the ending of WW a  years previously by producing one heart.The plan being that each heart would be included in at least one exhibition, ideally, as near to their home location.Thus making unique and thoughtful exhibitions to fulfil the hope of a generation not to be forgotten.Using cloth, thread and textile each heart interprets a unique story of comradeship, bravery, victory or setback told by those ing from the Great War or in their heartfelt letters to those back home.The hearts illustrate to a new generation the men and the animals that accompanied them the unorms worn and medals won the regiments that fought together and the family members fondly remembered the songs that kept their spirits high and the words they wrote to those back home. This is a one-off, not to be missed, opportunity to view the  Scottish Hearts in the North East of Scotland. title: msp backs bursary funding for stem roles
story: Career changers can now apply for a five-figure sum to support them while training to fill high-demand teaching roles in STEMsubjects.The move has been welcomed by Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin, a former college lecturer, who has previously backed encouraging more girls and women to take STEM subjects.A total of  bursaries are available in academic year   at a total cost of £ million - with Home Economics included for the first time.Applicants will be able to apply for a bursary of £,.Other STEM subjects in demand are Physics, Chemistry, Maths, Technical Education and Computing Science.Applications for bursaries have opened todayfor postgraduate teacher training courses beginning in August .Commenting, Gillian Martin MSP said: “This is a brilliant investment by the Scottish Government to help encourage more people to train in STEM subjects.“The development of skills in these subject areas will be vital for our future economy and will help to inspire the next generation of the Scottish workforce.“Bursaries like these will help to provide financial help and make it easier for people to make exciting career changes which will have an impact on pupils in the years ahead.”Skills Development Scotland Education Programme Lead Ken Edwards said: “The support offered by the STEM Bursary gives career changers the security to make the move from existing employment into teaching.“This will contribute to getting the right skills balance in the teaching workforce and in supporting young people to be engaged and enthused in their STEM learning.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. title: Roadworks to be carried out at four Caithness locations
story: ROAD improvements costing pound, are to be carried out at four Caithness locations, starting next week.The work, to be carried out by Bear Scotland, will begin at Hempriggs on the A on Monday and will conclude at Thrumster in April.A spokeswoman for the company said: "We have a pound, programme of road improvements planned across four locations in the Caithness area on the A and A in March and April."Starting on Monday, surfacing improvements will first take place on the A at Hempriggs for  days to address the worn-out road surface and localised rutted sections. Works will then move to the A south of Georgemas for  days from Monday, March , to carry out surfacing improvements on the route."A three-day patching project will then take place on the A Berriedale south brae which will address defects in the road surface, followed by an eight-day surfacing project for a stretch of the A at Thrumster in April."The spokeswoman said the projects will take place during the day, from am to pm, with no work planned at weekends to keep disruption to a minimum. A mph convoy system will be in place during working hours to escort traffic past the works areas at each location."Teams will do all they can to complete the projects as quickly and safely as possible. However, we encourage people to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date journey information," the spokeswoman added.Wick and east Caithness Highland councillor, Raymond Bremner, has been pressing for the road improvements on that section of the A and is "absolutely delighted" they are going ahead."The northbound side of the road has been in a deteriorating state of repair for some time and it certainly looked as though we were needing more than a pothole repair approach," he said. "I reviewed the road with an engineer in the spring of last year. As a result, and after a lot of discussion between the agencies, Bear and Transport Scotland, Irsquom delighted the remedial works are about to start."Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: accessibility top of the agenda for northlink
story: Changes are being made by NorthLink Ferries to make their services more accessible to all.On board information workshops and the introduction of new website software are the latest efforts being made by the company to improve services for those with additional support needs.The ferry operator implemented its new Recite Me accessibility tool on its website, this month, to make it more suitable to folk#s needs. The new software — which can be used on desktops and mobile browsers — allows website visitors to customise what they see and hear, from changing the contrast settings, language, font size and more.In the UK, there are estimated to be . million people with a learning disability and . million people who have English as a second language. ‘Recite Me’ has the ability to translate the NorthLink Ferries website into more than  languages — including Scots Gaelic . It can also translate text-to-speech to help visually impaired users and focus screen areas for those with dyslexia.On Monday, February , teams on board MV Hamnavoe hosted an Access Panel Orkney session, where staff were provided with disability awareness training. During the two-hour session, staff were able to experience what it’s like to have a disability by wearing glasses that simulated blindness, used wheelchairs and crutches and had their hearing dampened.Carolyn Grfiths of Access Panel Orkney said: “The aim of our session was to let staff experience disabilities first-hand so they can empathise with passengers’ needs.#All of us running the training have a disability so we were able to provide first-hand examples of what accessible travel is like for us. We were delighted to be welcomed on board to provide this training and it’s great to see a company like Serco NorthLink Ferries take accessibility for passengers seriously.”The MV Hjaltland will also host a Making Connections workshop today, Friday, February . The workshop will look at how passengers navigate potential barriers when changing from one mode of transport to another. Making Connections brings disabled people together with transport operators to discuss, address and plan how travel connections can be made easier.Seumas Campbell, customer service director at NorthLink Ferries, said: “Catering for passengers with ying degrees of disability is an important part of our service provision. Whether they are using our website to book their journey, making a connection from other forms of public transport or coming on board one of our vessels, we believe that passengers should experience a service that caters to all their needs.“The new website software will allow visitors to customise what they see and hear and as more and more visitors from around the world choose NorthLink Ferries to travel to the Northern Isles, ‘Recite Me’ is a great tool to help them plan and book their journey.“Our workshops are also a great way in training our staff on how they can best help and understand passengers’ needs. We pride ourselves on having a great team that always provides the best service so it’s important that we’re constantly refreshing their training.”For more information on accessibility for passengers on NorthLink Ferries, you can visit www.northlinkferries copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: PENTLAND Ferries and Strategic Marine Vietnam have announced the successful launch of the new vessel Alfred.At pm Vietnam time on Friday, well-wishers, invited guests, shipyard workers and Pentland Ferries team members lined the slipway as the completed hull of the ship rolled down the slipway and into the warm waters of where the vessel was built, Vung Tau, Vietnam.Since the keel was laid, approximately , tonnes of steel hull and aluminium superstructure have been welded together in a large workshop to create the flagship vessel for Pentland Ferries operations, named after Pentland Ferries managing director Andrew Banks# father Alfred Banks.The ship will carry  passengers and up to twelve lorries combined with  cars, or  cars in total.The final fit out of the interior will take place prior to a complete series of sea trials in Vietnam before Pentland Ferries crew sail Alfred back to home base in St Margaret#s Hope.Joseph Azran Alemberg SMV chief operating officer said: “Today’s a big day for Strategic Marine Vietnam and a proud moment for everyone that contributed to the vessel build. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons — Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat — also known as Repulse Bay — in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism — findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians — adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur welcomes fuel poverty re think
story: Orkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur has welcomed Scottish Government plans to ensure that its Fuel Poverty Bill recognises the higher costs faced by those living in remote rural and island areas.During the stage one debate in Parliament yesterday, Wednesday, the Housing Minister, Kevin Stewart indicated that he would bring forward amendments to the bill to include an ‘uplt’ to the minimum income standard for rural and island communities. Mr McArthur believes this reflects a change in approach by the government, after months of campaigning by the Orkney MSP and a range of organisations involved in tackling fuel poverty across the Highlands and Islands.During his remarks, Mr McArthur pointed out that when it comes to fuel poverty, rural and island areas are disproportionately affected, with Orkney having the highest proportion of households in fuel poverty and extreme fuel poverty anywhere in Scotland.Commenting after the debate, Mr McArthur said: “Fuel poverty blights communities across Scotland, but there is no doubt that it has a disproportionate impact on rural and island areas. Until recently, however, the Scottish Government appeared unwilling to recognise this fact or indeed the higher costs faced by those living in our rural and island communities.“Over recent months, working with a range of organisations with a wealth of experience and expertise in tackling fuel poverty, I have made the case for the Minister, Kevin Stewart to think again.  It was a case that the Local Government Committee was also persuaded to support.“I am delighted, therefore, that the Minister has had a change of heart and committed to bring forward amendments to his bill at stage two that better reflect the specic nature of fuel poverty in places like Orkney.  I look forward to seeing the detail of those amendments and will work with Mr Stewart, and local stakeholders in Orkney, to make sure we get this right.“Given the impact fuel poverty can have, not just on people’s quality of le but their physical and mental health, this bill has the potential to make a real dference.  For that to happen, it must be both effective and ambitious in eradicating fuel poverty from communities across the country.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: your chance to feedback on local buses
story: Bus Users Scotland will be seeking public feedback on Orkney bus services at two events in the county, this week. Today will see the first of these events — open to all — take place at Kirkwall Travel Centre from pm until pm, where folk will get a chance to air their views on how services can be improved. Tomorrow, Stromness Ferry Terminal will play host to the second of these sessions, from am until .pm.Representatives from both Stagecoach and Bus Users Scotland will be in attendance.Greig Mackay, deputy director for Bus Users Scotland said: “We are looking forward to ing to Orkney to hear the views of the bus passengers. We were really pleased with the engagement at our event last year and look forward to hearing from more of the locals on the bus services on the island.”David Liston, managing director for Stagecoach North Scotland said: “We always welcome feedback on the services we provide and there is no better way to gather this than to host an event in partnership with Bus Users Scotland. The feedback we received last year really helped us to develop improvements across the island demonstrated by the enhancements we made to services throughout the summer in . title: Ambitious plan sets goals to end fuel poverty
story: PEOPLE across Ross-shire could benefit after the Scottish Government incorporated changes into its own draft legislation to ldquoend the scourge of fuel poverty.An earlier barrage of criticism claimed the Fuel Poverty Bill missed the target when it came to delivering for the ldquoworst affected areas.Fuel poverty is defined as when households spend  per cent or more of income on domestic fuel ndash reckoned to account for one in four homes in Scotland.The figure is understood to be signicantly higher across swathes of Ross-shire, hitting homes which are not on the gas grid and reliant on oil and low-income households.Minister for local government, housing and planning, Kevin Stewart, promised to include ldquoa rural, remote and island minimum income standard in poverty calculations as well as what he called ldquoa rural uplt.He was speaking at the first stage of a Holyrood debate of the Bill which aims to cut fuel-poor households to five per cent by  from the current national average of almost  per cent.The move was welcomed by rural housing associations and local councillors but Highlands Tory MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston vowed to maintain pressure on the government to deliver on what was promised.He said: "The minister announced that a new rural, remote and island minimum income standard will be included in their fuel poverty calculations alongside a rural uplt. We will be looking to strengthen the Bill as it progresses through the Scottish Parliament and ensuring that the Scottish Governmentrsquos pledges are met."Before Wednesdayrsquos debate Mr Stewart said: ldquoWithin this ground-breaking legislation, not only are we one of the few countries in the world to define fuel poverty, we are also setting a goal towards eradicating it.ldquoBy changing the definition of fuel poverty so itrsquos more closely aligned to relative income poverty and taking steps to ensure it works for remote rural and island communities, we are ensuring our support is focussed on those who need it most."He added: "In this day and age, it is unacceptable that any Scottish household should have to choose between having the heating on and cooking their dinner.Councillor Ian Cockburn, who represents the Wester Ross, Strathpeffer and Lochalsh welcomed the Bill as "something has to be done about fuel poverty" while arguing it is also time to rethink infrastructure like the national grid."It is ambitious but has to be tried to get fuel poverty down in rural areas. We are one of the most energy rich countries in the world so we should be able to get something done. Too many people take it as just being part of the landscape up here so we need to change that thinking as well to get people the assistance that they need."Scotland should not be in this state. But you have to look back, the National Grid was set up at the end of the war, the Highlands is considered off-grid despite supplying much of the rest of the country through hydro and wind power. It is time for a rethink."Calum Macaulay, chief executive of Invergordon-based Albyn Housing Society, said: ldquoWe welcome this development in the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach to addressing fuel poverty in rural areas. The push to include minimum income standards feels like a signicant step forwards. This is something that the Rural and Islands Housing Association Forum has been promoting for quite some time."This has included research undertaken with the support of Highlands and Islands Enterprise and others into minimum income standards in rural communities. The results of this highlighted the pressures of lower average household incomes and higher average fuel costs across the northern parts of Scotland."What do you think  Share your views by emailing newsdesk@spp-groupTuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle authors French connection helps ensure nothing is lost in translation
story: Vee Walkers Major Toms War, partly set in France during WWI, is now fittingly being translated into French for a new edition of the book.Such has been the response to the novel that the Black Isle author has already been on a book tour and visited France on the back of it. The annual Franco-Scottish Society Alexander Gray Fund Lecture in Inverness on Friday promises to be alight-hearted bilingual talk from Ms Walker and her "long-suffering" Parisian translator Richard Kausch.Major Tomrsquos War is a moving novel set in France during the First World War, in part in the grim lsquozones occupeacuteesrsquo of northern France.Its characters are real people ndash and both author and translator have had to enter the minds of the novelrsquos key protagonists.The novel is published in English by Kashi House in London and the French edition should follow late this year or early in .Veeand Richard will be touring four of the regional Franco-Scottish Societies of Scotland this month.The groups exist to foster French language and culture in Scotland and meet monthly for French conversation or a lecture.Those who come along are welcome to join or to attend as a non-member. They are suitable for Higher Advanced Higher French pupils and their teachers.Vee confesses that as a French-speaking author she has not madeher translatorsle any easier: "Most translators produce a translation and the author would not have a clue about whether or not it is representative or accurate."My first degree was in French and although I am not a native speaker, I have had an opinion on nuance and vocabulary right the way through."Richard is currently revising the French text a second time to address the changes requested by my English publishers for the First Edition. He has the patience of a saint and I donrsquot know what I would have done without him!"Wersquore both looking forward to meeting audiences in Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Inverness on our tour around Scotland very much."Vee and Richardrsquos final tour slot is in Inverness on Friday, February  at the Glen Mhor Hotel,  Ness Bank, Invernessat .pm.Thelecture is free and will be followed by a French meal atpm. Theres a fixed menu.Reservations can be booked on   for lecture and or meal. Themeal is pound to members andpound to non-members.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Call for flexibility over closure of Rosemarkie toilets
story: FEARS are intensying over the future of public toilets in Rosemarkie after Highland Council revealed that it would only keep them open until the end of March.The th hour news appears to fly in the face of assurances given to local community leaders at a meeting last November and has sparked a petition that has already got more than  signatures from worried locals calling for the council to keep the facility open.It had been hoped a charitable trust could be set up to take over the running of the facility, a process anticipated to take months, but time for that is running out and in the meantime it is feared harm could be done to the villagersquos appeal as a visitor destination.The well-loved and well-respected Groam House Museum could be impacted as well, with staff and visitors both needing to use the public convenience as there are no facilities on the premises.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoA draft temporary lease is being drawn up to enable the planned Community Development Trust to be taken forward. If the facility is not taken on by the community then it will close on March as per report to the Highland Council [on] October .ldquoNo survey will be undertaken, the facility will transfer in lsquoas seen, as isrsquo condition, the facilities will transfer in their current operational condition. The position of toilets remaining open whilst negotiations are ongoing is for this financial year only. There is no budget to retain facilities... which is why we want to get the leases sorted out before the end of March.Despite that the director of the Groam House Museum Doug Maclean, who recently attended a meeting of the community council where the future of the toilets was on the agenda remains hopeful.ldquoWe are confident that by some means or other, through a charitable trust taking over the running of the toilets and the good services of the local people, we will be able to keep the toilets open, he said.However, Mr Maclean was in no doubt about how serious an effect the closure would have on Rosemarkie as well as Groam House Museum.ldquoFrom the museumrsquos point of view it is absolutely vital for our existence. We have groups of school children that come here and of course children need to go to the toilet, he said.ldquoWe also have groups of mainly elderly American tourists and they are not in a position to make their way to the beach cafeacute. And we would lose both those groups without the toilets which put the museum in jeopardy.Black Isle ward councillor Gordon Adam said: ldquoI am in discussions with the council over the time limit of March , my view is that the council needs to be flexible. Savings have to be made, but sticking rigidly to a timetable leaves little time to form development groups.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Conon Bridge pupils injury sparks community discussion
story: AN accident at a Ross-shire school which left a child with a badly broken leg will be discussed by Conon Bridge Community Council.Max McPhee was five when a large stone fell from a boundary wall at Ben Wyvis Primary School in May , crushing his leg.After months of treatment the youngster, now seven, has been left with one leg cm shorter than the other. This week it emerged that the boy had won legal action against Highland Council.The local authority, whose former chief executive Steve Barron had to apologise to parents for a series of faults with the building after its completion, had denied liability throughout the civil action.But it backed down when the boyrsquos solicitor Digby Brown proved it knew of an earlier debris fall one year before Max was injured.Secretary of Conon Bridge Community Council John Bruce said the matter will be on their agenda at their meeting next Wednesday.At the time of Maxrsquos accident, the chairwoman of the community council, Fiona MacKintosh, said there had been a catalogue of repairs to the pound million school since it opened in  including the closure of the main games hall.After the settlement was announced Maxrsquos mum Louiseaccused the council of acting shamefully over her sonrsquos injury. She said: ldquoItrsquos shocking that Highland Council didnrsquot have the decency to hold their hands up and just help a little boy who was hurt by their own failings.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoIt is the councilrsquos policy not to comment on insurance claims.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Funding blow to Ross shire alcohol support service
story: ALCOHOLISM support in Ross-shire has been dealt a blow after a group that helps people fight addiction announced its closure ndash amid funding cuts and increasing red tape.The board of Alcohol Counselling Services Ross and Sutherland , which has been supporting people in the region for more than  years, has ldquosadly and regretfully decided that the service will close from April .News of the closure has been greeted with dismay by recovering addicts, one of whom, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that without the service their ldquooutcome could have been very dferent.Explaining the reasons for the closure, the servicersquos co-ordinator, Chris Cochrane, said: ldquoThis decision has not been taken lightly. There are many reasons why this course of action is necessary, the main one being the struggle to secure sufficient finances to run the organisation.About pound, to pound, is needed annually but Ms Cochrane said that the NHS is doing a review of third sector input, and can only confirm funding up to June.Without the support of the NHS, they will find it dficult to win the support of other funding bodies.The news will be a blow to the  service users currently on the books of ACSRS many of whom faced a personal battle before seeking help and then keeping on attending to receive the support on offer.However Ms Cochrane said they will do everything in their power to ensure their clients receive alternative assistance with their dependency. Around  people with alcohol dependency are referred to them each year.She said: ldquoThe board is actively pursuing alternative arrangements for our service users and volunteer counsellors who wish to continue their support or volunteering.ldquoACSRS has been indebted to many people over the years who have given their time and expertise freely as volunteers. Some have assisted in the management of the service as board members providing governance and support for staff and volunteers.ldquoOthers have given thousands of hours of their free time as trained volunteer counsellors. There are six counsellors and not all of them will be wanting to move on though some might seek paid employment.ldquoThe training for these counsellors was previously provided free. It now requires a source of additional funding.ldquoAs for other voluntary organisations, the burden of bureaucracy has increased without the corresponding increase in income, and the task of securing additional funding has become more challenging.ldquoACSRS is the only voluntary organisation within Ross-shire and Sutherland offering a free professional one-to-one counselling service for those affected by their own or a loved onersquos addiction. Our work complements the work done by NHS Drug and Alcohol Recovery staff.ldquoWe would like to thank all those people for their extremely valuable contributions which made it possible for us to serve our community for over  years.Councillor Margaret Paterson, Dingwall and Seaforth, said: ldquoI know this group and this will be a dreadful loss as they give a tremendous service. It is quite distressing to hear this because they have given people with addiction and their families such help for so many years. Their volunteers have given such time and talent to help the vulnerable in society, butthey donrsquot have money then they just canrsquot do it. I hope that something can be done to continue their good work.Two service users who wished to remain anonymous praised ACSRS for the help they received. One said: ldquoI can honestly say that ACSRS played a major part in my recovery. If that help was not there when I needed it, the outcome could have been very dferent.The other said: ldquoHearing a voice that was willing to listen to me was a relief on one of the darkest days of my le.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Invergordon ports plans put on public display
story: MORE than  members of the public took the opportunity to get a closer look at the Port of Cromarty Firthrsquos ambitious poundm expansion plans.The public information event in the port offices in Invergordon on Wednesday afternoon also allowed visitors to ask questions about the scheme. title: Landmark anniversary for Ullapool arts hub
story: ONE of the countryrsquos smallest independent art schools is set to celebrate a major milestone by marking the st anniversary of its flagship course.Bridge House Art in Ullapool has been running its Portfolio Course since the late rsquos.In that time the school has built a growing reputation and has hosted students from as far afield as Lithuania, France, Switzerland, Spain and the USA.And on Sunday will celebrate the anniversary with its annual exhibition of portfolio course work ndash following an intensive four month training in the visual arts for  people from across the UK and mainland Europe.RESONANCE opens and will run daily from am to pm to March  at An Talla Solais Gallery, West Argyle Street, Ullapool and entry is free.It promises to be an eclectic mix of drawing, painting, printmaking, jewellery and illustration. Much of the work will be available for sale.Eleanor White, founder and principal tutor said: ldquoThe ethos behind all of our courses is to encourage everybody to learn to communicate visually and express a genuine response to the environment around us. I have been delighted with the way this yearrsquos students have responded to the challenge, this promises to be an excellent exhibition.Coming from a range of ages and backgrounds, the students have one thing in common ndash a shared desire to develop as artists. The -week course covers a range of disciplines including painting, printmaking, textiles and sculpture. Each inidual spends the second term developing a themed body of work and these will be on show at the exhibition.Kittie Jones, senior tutor and award-winning professional artist, said: ldquoI am always impressed by the dedication, hard work and motivation of the students on this course, many of them have moved up here to be part of the course and the results speak for themselves.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Mystery oil tank artist adds a splash of colour to Invergordon
story: ITrsquoS a site steeped in local history and a lasting legacy to Invergordonrsquos nautical history.But the disused fuel tanks which stored the oil which powered some of the Royal Navyrsquos greatest warships during World War II has been a blight on the landscape of the Easter Ross port for generations.Recently, however, a graffiti artist has been hard at work beautying some of the relics, doing a lsquoBanksyrsquo with colourful images at the giant Seabank fuel tanks near the railway line, adding to lots of mural street art in the town already undertaken by the Invergordon Off The Wall group.Now the search is on to find the mystery painter who has already made a start on a canvas of over  massive tanks to choose from.Local woman Jacqueline Brown said she wasnrsquot sure exactly when the artwork was done: ldquoBut we would love to find out who is doing it.ldquoThe site really is out of bounds to the public but people go in and walk their dogs. I think I first saw the murals last year and they are quite stunning. Whoever is doing it is obviously very talented. Itrsquos a fascinating site. We know Invergordon became a naval town and was the base for the Home Fleet in World War I. These tanks were built for the supply of fuel to warships and they were in use until the mid-s.Mrs Brown said like many street artists, the person who carried out the work may wish to remain anonymous and even be fearful of prosecution.ldquoI just donrsquot know. But what they have done is quite beautul. I am sure we could find more projects for them in Invergordon including the town house which the community wants to take back into public ownership.A website documenting historical and derelict places in Scotland reveals the depot was built in conjunction with secret oil storage tanks a few miles away.It records the underground tanks were built to hold  million gallons of oil fuel and were built into a solid rock hill to protect it from bombs.On February ,  a Junkers  is reported to have carried out a solo attack on the tank farm, dropping two lb bombs damaging two tanks. But none of the bombs exploded although they cause a major spillage of oil.Mrs Brown said she understood there were plans to remove some tanks to build houses. She said: ldquoBut it takes time for these sites to be decontaminated from their former industrial uses.In , flats built in Joss Street had to be demolished because the site, which had been formerly used as a gas works, hadnrsquot been properly decontaminated.What do you think  Share your views by emailing us at newsdesk@spp-groupTuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...SCOTTISH Labour leader Richard Leonard has said he#d rather have a Labour Brexit deal than a second EU referendum - but that he would still back Remaina second vote was held.Mr Leonard said thatLabour’s five point Brexit plan was not adopted by Theresa May in Westminster then there should be a second public vote on leaving the EU.But he admitted that a second EU referendum could also see an increase in demand for a another Scottish independence vote.Speaking after he addressed his group of MSPs, he said: “If we are not successful in amending the Theresa May deal then we feel we are left with no option than to back a public vote. “We have said we are looking for signicant changes to the deal that is on the table - a permanent Customs Union, close alignment with the Single Market, guarantees around the rights and protections people have as workers and consumers and environmental protections and collaboration with the EU around security and arrest warrants - and so my preference is for that deal.”However he saidLabour was unsuccessful he would back a second referendum but that it must include both Remain and “a credible Leave option” on the ballot.“I am worried about Labour voters who voted Leave. I would be concernedpeople who voted Leave felt abandoned by the Labour Party. But we are trying to steer a way through what is a very dficult situation created by Theresa May,” he said.“Our strategy has been to try and hold the country together. title: brexit second referendum takes a step closer to reality leader comment
story: A second Brexit referendum would need to ensure all sides of the debate were able to express their opinion.Labour has taken a long time to come round to the idea, but a week after a group of pro-Remain MPs quit the party to form the Independent Group, it has finally decided to push for a second Brexit referendum.Theresa May’s proposed deal is far from the vision that won the support of  per cent of voters in the  referendum and is even opposed by the most ardent of Brexiteers, people like Nigel Farage and Jacob Rees-Mogg.According to existing UK law, the only other alternative is a no-deal Brexit, which would quite clearly cause serious damage to the UK economy and should not be considered as an option by anyone with the UK’s national interests at heart.Labour is now set to back an amendment to rule out a no-deal and will also put forward its own Brexit plan for a “permanent and comprehensive customs union” and “close alignment with the single markets”.This may or may not be realistic – given the EU’s stance against a re-negotiation – but Jeremy Corbyn added that Labour would back “an amendment in favour of a public vote to prevent a damaging Tory Brexit being forced on the country”. David Lammy, a prominent Remain-supporting Labour MP, said Corbyn was “taking the first step to reunite our party by showing he is listening to our voters and members on this, the biggest issue of our time”.: Brexit: Labour to back second referendum in parliamentIt is often said that the EU referendum was held in an attempt to solve an internecine war within the Conservative party. Now, it seems, Labour’s internal troubles could bring about another one.Clearly, the chances of this actually happening will depend on the attitude of many Conservative MPs – and not just Remain ones. Labour’s decision could simply prompt Brexiteer MPs to drop their opposition to May’s deal, fearing the ‘will of the people’ is now pro-Remain.But,a second vote does come about, the big question will be the question. BrexitRef would undoubtedly be a isive affair and there would be a serious risk of a boycott by Brexiteers, which could cause potentially irreparable harm to democracy in this country.So considerable efforts would need to be made to try to bring Farage, Rees-Mogg and the like on board. And the question would have to be one that allowed all sides of this most tortuous debate to have their final – final – say on the matter.: Brexit: The Scotsman calls for second referendum – leader comment©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: oscars 2019 hollywood reveals its true colours once again dr claire jenkins
story: Another year, another Oscars Ceremony. Red-carpeted self-congratulations, the popping of flashes and the anticipation of the popping of corks at the many after parties for the rich and famous. And, once again, another Academy Awards in which no women were mentioned in the important category of best director, writes Dr Claire Jenkins.In the  years that the awards have been running, only five women have been nominated for this coveted award – and only one, Kathryn Bigelow, has come away with the statuette: this represents about one per cent of nominees and winners. It’s a shockingly low statistic, even when you take into account that a mere eight per cent of Hollywood’s top  films in  were directed by women. In  America’s Equal Employment Opportunity Commission found Hollywood to be guilty of discrimination against female directors, but as yet there have been no signicant shts in the number of women directing.  But while there is clearly much to do, there may be some small tremors discernible on Hollywood’s Geiger counter. Take Mimi Leder‘s newest film On the Basis of Sex, about the career of US Supreme Court justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Leder was effectively ostracised by Hollywood after the commercial failure of Pay it Forward , so herto directing with a biopic of one of America’s most prominent feminist icons suggests that Hollywood is softening in its treatment of women on, and off, screen.  Leder’sto the director’s chair comes alongside the impressive success of Ava DuVernay, who has been breaking ground for women of colour in the film industry. DuVernay became the first African-American woman to make over USm at the American domestic box office with A Wrinkle in Timeand was subsequently offered a m deal with Warner Bros. This deal came despite the film’s lukewarm critical reception, and claims that it was helped to box office success by The Incredibles , with which it was paired at ious drive-ins in the US. It should be noted that DuVernay’s deal with Warner Bros was to develop television content. It is in the television and streaming sectors that women seem to have more opportunities. It was as a television director that Leder has been working since her film career faltered, gaining acclaim for her work on The Leftovers, and DuVernay has oscillated between television and film – taking on a number of producing roles for the small screen.  : Oscars : Olivia Colman named best actress in shock win  The current Hollywood climate continues to favour male filmmakers, with its penchant for high-octane action blockbusters and superhero movies that are more often than not films for – and about – men. Coverage of the forthcoming Captain Marvel movie may be trying to draw on the film’s feminist credentials – with its female lead and female director – but Anna Boden is only one half of the directorial team . So despite Marvel boss Kevin Feige’s claims that “many” of the upcoming Marvel films will be directed by women, as yet no movie from what is known as the “Marvel Cinematic Universe”has a female director, although Australian director Cate Shortland is expected to helm the Black Widow film.  EvenMCU and other action-producers continue to hire women directors, though, this will not necessarily affect the Oscars – Black Panther currently standing as the only MCU movie to be nominated.  Big-budget, but low-brow action movies are generally overlooked during awards season – instead it’s those films that we might term “Indiewood”, independent-style films funded or distributed by specialist arms of the major studios, that tend to be celebrated. In , two of the three English language films nominated for best director were distributed by major studios, or their specialist arms. The Favourite was distributed by Fox Searchlight, and BlacKkKlansman was distributed by Focus Features, a subsidiary of Universal.  Independent filmmaking has, historically, offered more opportunities for women directors, and therefore the lack of women nominated for the Best Director award seems even more pronounced. Although figures for women working within the independent sector are less well publicised, the Celluloid Ceiling Report suggested that women are better represented in the independent sector, making up  per cent of the directors of narrative features screened at festivals in  and .  : Academy refuses to pull James Bulger film from Oscars despite family’s plea  Statistics such as these demonstrate that women directors are working in the American industry, but the big studios are failing to hire them and the Academy is failing to recognise them.  Women directors slated for nods this awards season all made films that fall into the independent or Indiewood category: Debra Granik’s Leave No Trace, Lynne Ramsay’s You Were Never Really Here and Marielle Heller’s Can You Ever Forgive Me.  Anne Fletcher’s latest film Dumplin’ was independently produced and distributed by Netflix. Fletcher had box office success with mainstream rom-coms including  Dressesand The Proposalbut after the failure of Hot Pursuit it appears that she too has been pushed out of the mainstream.  That Dumplin’ was distributed by Netflix, and You Were Never Really Here was distributed by Amazon Studios, demonstrates that there are dferent outlets for women within the changing media culture but there is still a lack of support for women in the mainstream – the big studios. And even those women who have had success in Hollywood are rarely recognised for their achievements.  The death of Penny Marshall in December was met with a public outpouring of grief via social media and popular press. She was hailed as a trailblazer as the first woman to make over m at the American domestic box office with Big . But Marshall is not a household name. Big is remembered as the film that made Tom Hanks’ name, not Marshall’s. Marshall is just the first in a long string of women who have changed Hollywood, but they are not recognised for their achievements.  The American film industry must do better – in hiring women directors, in rewarding women directors and in highlighting and protecting their legacies.  Dr Claire Jenkins is a lecturer in film and television studies at Leicester University.
